This is his third arrest, and Steve claims the police are picking on him ever since an elderly lady in the community gave him $5,000 when he was out of work. He intends to pay her back when his ship comes in. Steve's wife of 3 years left him recently, claiming he couldn't hold a decent job and was running up bills they couldn't pay. Steve was tired of her nagging and was ready for a new relationship anyway. He wishes he could win the lottery and find a beautiful girl to love him. He's tired of people demanding that he grow up, get a job, and settle down. They just don't understand that he's got more exciting things to do.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-care-plan-antisocial-personality-disorder">NURSING CARE PLAN: ANTISOCIAL PERSONALITY DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-antisocial-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>767</p>
<p>Ineffective Coping: Inability to form a valid appraisal of the stressors, inadequate choices of practiced responses, and/or inability to use available resources</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assessment-data">ASSESSMENT DATA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Low frustration tolerance</li>
<li>Impulsive behavior</li>
<li>Inability to delay gratification</li>
<li>Poor judgment</li>
<li>Conflict with authority</li>
<li>Difficulty following rules and obeying laws</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expected-outcomes">EXPECTED OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="immediate">Immediate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immediate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Refrain from harming self or others throughout hospitalization.</li>
<li>Identify behaviors leading to hospitalization within 24 to 48 hours.</li>
<li>Function within the limits of the therapeutic milieu; for example, follow no-smoking rules, participate in group activities within 2 to 3 days.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stabilization">Stabilization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stabilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Demonstrate nondestructive ways to deal with stress and frustration.</li>
<li>Identify ways to meet own needs that do not infringe on the rights of others.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="community">Community<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Achieve or maintain satisfactory work performance.</li>
</ul>
<p>768</p>
<ul>
<li>Meet own needs without exploiting or infringing on the rights of others.</li>
</ul>
<p>IMPLEMENTATION</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Nursing Interventions</th><th>Rationale</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Encourage the client to identify the actions that precipitated hospitalization (e.g., debts, marital problems, law violation).</td><td>These clients frequently deny responsibility for the consequences of their own actions.</td></tr><tr><td>Give positive feedback for honesty. The client may try to avoid responsibility by acting as though he or she is “sick” or helpless.</td><td>Honest identification of the consequences of the client’s behavior is necessary for future behavior change.</td></tr><tr><td>Identify unacceptable behaviors, either general (stealing others’ possessions) or specific (embarrassing another by telling lewd jokes).</td><td>You must supply clear, concrete limits when the client is unable or unwilling to do so.</td></tr><tr><td>Develop specific consequences for unacceptable behaviors (e.g., the client may not watch television).</td><td>Unpleasant consequences may help decrease or eliminate unacceptable behaviors. The consequences must be related to something the client enjoys, to be effective.</td></tr><tr><td>Avoid any discussion about why requirements exist. State the requirement in a matter-of-fact manner. Avoid arguing with the client.</td><td>The client may attempt to bend the rules “just this once” with numerous excuses and justifications. Your refusal to be manipulated or charmed will help decrease manipulative behavior.</td></tr><tr><td>Inform the client of unacceptable behaviors and the resulting consequences before they occur.</td><td>The client must be aware of expectations and consequences.</td></tr><tr><td>Communicate and document in the client’s care plan all behaviors and consequences in specific terms.</td><td>The client may attempt to gain favor with individual staff members or play one staff member against another (“Last night, the nurse told me I could do that”). If all team members follow the written plan, the client will not be able to manipulate changes.</td></tr><tr><td>Avoid discussing another staff member’s actions or statements unless the other staff member is present.</td><td>The client may try to manipulate staff members or focus attention on others to decrease attention to him or herself.</td></tr><tr><td>Be consistent and firm with the care plan. Do not</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>make independent changes in rules or consequences. Any change should be made by the staff as a group and conveyed to all staff members working with this client. (You may designate a primary staff person to be responsible for minor decisions and refer all questions to this person.)*</th><th>Consistency is essential. If the client can find just one person to make independent changes, any plan will become ineffective.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Avoid trying to coax or convince the client to do the “right thing.”</td><td>The client must decide to accept responsibility for his or her behavior and its consequences.</td></tr><tr><td>When the client exceeds a limit, provide consequences immediately after the behavior in a matter-of-fact manner.</td><td>Consequences are most effective when they closely follow the unacceptable behavior. Do not react to the client in an angry or punitive manner. If you show anger toward the client, he or she may take advantage of it. It is better to get out of the situation if possible and let someone else handle it.</td></tr><tr><td>Point out the client’s responsibility for his or her behavior in a nonjudgmental manner.</td><td>The client needs to learn the connection between behavior and the consequences, but blame and judgment are not appropriate.</td></tr><tr><td>Provide immediate positive feedback or reward for acceptable behavior.</td><td>Immediate positive feedback will help increase acceptable behavior. The client must receive attention for positive behaviors, not just unacceptable ones.</td></tr><tr><td>Gradually, require longer periods of acceptable behavior and greater rewards, and inform the client of changes as decisions are made. For example, at first the client must demonstrate acceptable behavior for 2 hours to earn 1 hour of television time. Gradually, the client could progress to 5 days of acceptable behavior and earn a 2-day weekend pass.</td><td>This gradual progression will help develop the client’s ability to delay gratification. This is necessary if the client is to function effectively in society.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to identify sources of frustration, how he or she dealt with it previously, and any unpleasant consequences that resulted.</td><td>This may facilitate the client’s ability to accept responsibility for his or her own behavior.</td></tr><tr><td>Explore alternative, socially and legally acceptable methods of dealing with identified frustrations.</td><td>The client has the opportunity to learn to make alternative choices.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>770</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Help the client try alternatives as situations arise. Give positive feedback when the client uses alternatives successfully.</th><th>The client can role-play alternatives in a nonthreatening environment.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Discuss job seeking, work attendance, court appearances, and so forth when working with the client in anticipation of discharge.*</td><td>Dealing with consequences and working are responsible behaviors. The client may have had little or no successful experience in these areas and may benefit from assistance.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>*Collaborative interventions.</p>
<p>Adapted from Schultz, J. M., &amp; Videbeck, S. L. (2013). Lippincott's manual of psychiatric care plans (9th ed.). Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams &amp; Wilkins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="enhancing-role-performance">Enhancing Role Performance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#enhancing-role-performance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nurse helps clients to identify specific problems at work or home that are barriers to success in fulfilling roles. Assessing use of alcohol and other drugs is essential when examining role performance because many clients use or abuse these substances. These clients tend to blame others for their failures and difficulties, and the nurse must redirect them to examine the source of their problems realistically. Referrals to vocational or job programs may be indicated.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-1e78ad80.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg"></p>
<p>Problem-solving skills</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="client-and-family-education">CLIENT AND FAMILY EDUCATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#client-and-family-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-antisocial-personality-disorder">For Antisocial Personality Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-antisocial-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Avoiding use of alcohol and other drugs</li>
<li>Appropriate social skills</li>
<li>Effective problem-solving skills</li>
<li>Managing emotions such as anger and frustration</li>
<li>Taking a time-out to avoid stressful situations</li>
</ul>
<p>772</p>
<p>773</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="evaluation">Evaluation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#evaluation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nurse evaluates the effectiveness of treatment based on attainment of or progress toward outcomes. If a client can maintain a job with acceptable performance, meet basic family responsibilities, and avoid committing illegal or immoral acts, then treatment has been successful.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="borderline-personality-disorder">BORDERLINE PERSONALITY DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#borderline-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>BPD is characterized by a pervasive pattern of unstable interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affect as well as marked impulsivity. About 2% to 3% of the general population has BPD; it is five times more common in those with a first-degree relative with the diagnosis. BPD is the most common personality disorder found in clinical settings. It is three times more common in women than in men. Under stress, transient psychotic symptoms are common. Between 8% and 10% of people with this diagnosis commit suicide, and many more suffer permanent damage from self-mutilation injuries, such as cutting or burning. Up to three-quarters of clients with BPD engage in deliberate self-harm, sometimes called <strong>nonsuicidal self-injury</strong> (Merza, Papp, Molnar, &amp; Szabo, 2017). Typically, recurrent self-mutilation is a cry for help, an expression of intense anger or helplessness, or a form of self-punishment. The resulting physical pain is also a means to block emotional pain. Clients who engage in self-mutilation do so to reinforce that they are still alive; they seek to experience physical pain in the face of emotional numbing.</p>
<p>Working with clients who have BPD can be frustrating. They may cling and ask for help 1 minute and then become angry, act out, and reject all offers of help in the next minute. They may attempt to manipulate staff to gain immediate gratification of needs and, at times, sabotage their own treatment plans by purposely failing to do what they have agreed. Their labile mood, unpredictability, and diverse behaviors can make it seem as if the staff is always “back to square one” with them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="application-of-the-nursing-process-borderline-personality-disorder">APPLICATION OF THE NURSING PROCESS: BORDERLINE PERSONALITY DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#application-of-the-nursing-process-borderline-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>774</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment">Assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">History<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many of these clients report disturbed early relationships with their parents that often begin at 18 to 30 months of age. Commonly, early attempts by these clients to achieve developmental independence were met with punitive responses from parents or threats of withdrawal of parental support and approval. Of these clients, 50% have experienced childhood sexual abuse; others have experienced physical and verbal abuse and parental alcoholism. Clients tend to use transitional objects (e.g., teddy bears, pillows, blankets, and dolls) extensively; this may continue into adulthood. Transitional objects are often similar to favorite items from childhood that the client used for comfort or security (Kiefer et al., 2017).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-appearance-and-motor-behavior">General Appearance and Motor Behavior<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-appearance-and-motor-behavior" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients experience a wide range of dysfunction from severe to mild. Initial behavior and presentation may vary widely depending on a client's present status. When dysfunction is severe, clients may appear disheveled and may be unable to sit still, or they may display labile emotions. In other cases, initial appearance and motor behavior may seem normal. The client seen in the emergency department threatening suicide or self-harm may seem out of control, while a client seen in an outpatient clinic may appear fairly calm and rational.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mood-and-affect">Mood and Affect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mood-and-affect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pervasive mood is dysphoric, involving unhappiness, restlessness, and malaise. Clients often report intense loneliness, boredom, frustration, and feeling "empty." They rarely experience periods of satisfaction or well-being. Although there is a pervasive depressed affect, it is unstable and erratic. Clients may become irritable, even hostile or sarcastic, and complain of episodes of panic anxiety. They experience intense emotions such as anger and rage but rarely express them productively or usefully. They are usually hypersensitive to others' emotions, which can easily trigger reactions. Minor changes may precipitate a severe emotional crisis, for example, when an appointment must be changed from one day to the next. Commonly, these clients experience major emotional trauma when their therapists take vacations.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-baf8b44f.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<p>Unstable, unhappy affect of borderline personality disorder</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thought-process-and-content">Thought Process and Content<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thought-process-and-content" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Thinking about oneself and others is often polarized and extreme, which is sometimes referred to as splitting. Clients tend to adore and idealize other people even after a brief acquaintance but then quickly devalue them if these others do not meet their expectations in some way. Clients have excessive and chronic fears of abandonment even in normal situations; this reflects their intolerance of being alone. They may also engage in obsessive rumination about almost anything, regardless of the issue's relative importance.</p>
<p>Clients may experience dissociative episodes (periods of wakefulness when they are unaware of their actions). Self-harm behaviors often occur during these dissociative episodes, though, at other times, clients may be fully aware of injuring themselves. As stated earlier, under extreme stress,</p>
<p>775</p>
<p>clients may develop transient psychotic symptoms such as delusions or hallucinations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sensorium-and-intellectual-processes">Sensorium and Intellectual Processes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensorium-and-intellectual-processes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Intellectual capacities are intact, and clients are fully oriented to reality. The exception is transient psychotic symptoms; during such episodes, reports of auditory hallucinations encouraging or demanding self-harm are most common. These symptoms usually abate when the stress is relieved. Many clients also report flashbacks of previous abuse or trauma. These experiences are consistent with posttraumatic stress disorder, which is common in clients with BPD (see Chapter 13).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="judgment-and-insight">Judgment and Insight<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#judgment-and-insight" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients frequently report behaviors consistent with impaired judgment and lack of care and concern for safety, such as gambling, shoplifting, and reckless driving. They make decisions impulsively on the basis of emotions rather than facts.</p>
<p>Clients have difficulty accepting responsibility for meeting needs outside a relationship. They see life's problems and failures as a result of others' shortcomings. Because others are always to blame, insight is limited. A typical reaction to a problem is "I wouldn't have gotten into this mess if so-and-so had been there."</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="self-concept">Self-Concept<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-concept" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients have an unstable view of themselves that shifts dramatically and suddenly. They may appear needy and dependent one moment and angry, hostile, and rejecting the next. Sudden changes in opinions and plans about career, sexual identity, values, and types of friends are common. Clients view themselves as inherently bad or evil and often report feeling as if they don't really exist at all.</p>
<p>Suicidal threats, gestures, and attempts are common. Self-harm and mutilation, such as cutting, punching, or burning, are common. These behaviors must be taken seriously because these clients are at increased risk for completed suicide, even if numerous previous attempts have not been life-threatening. These self-inflicted injuries cause much pain and often require extensive treatment; some result in massive scarring or permanent disability such as paralysis or loss of mobility from injury to nerves, tendons, and other essential structures.</p>
<p>776</p>
<p>44 Concept Mastery Alert</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="borderline-personality-disorder">Borderline Personality Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#borderline-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>People with borderline personality disorder (BPD) have an extreme fear of abandonment and a history of unstable, insecure attachments. These individuals, who already are intensely emotional and have a poor sense of self, feel estranged from others and inadequate in meeting perceived social standards. The pervasive mood is dysphoric, involving unhappiness, restlessness, and malaise. Clients often report intense loneliness and feeling “empty,” which causes them to rarely experience periods of satisfaction or well-being that would lead to exaggerated self-image. Clients tend to have an unstable view of themselves that shifts dramatically and suddenly, often from needy and dependent one moment to angry, hostile, and rejecting the next.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="roles-and-relationships">Roles and Relationships<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#roles-and-relationships" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients hate being alone, but their erratic, labile, and sometimes dangerous behaviors often isolate them. Relationships are unstable, stormy, and intense; the cycle repeats itself continually. These clients have extreme fears of abandonment and difficulty believing a relationship still exists once the person is away from them. They engage in many desperate behaviors, even suicide attempts, to gain or maintain relationships. Feelings for others are often distorted, erratic, and inappropriate. For example, they may view someone they have met only once or twice as their best and only friend or the “love of my life.” If another person does not immediately reciprocate their feelings, they may feel rejected, become hostile, and declare him or her to be their enemy. These erratic emotional changes can occur in the space of an hour. Often, these situations precipitate self-mutilating behavior; occasionally, clients may attempt to harm others physically.</p>
<p>Clients usually have a history of poor school and work performance because of constantly changing career goals and shifts in identity or aspirations, preoccupation with maintaining relationships, and fear of real or perceived abandonment. Clients lack the concentration and self-discipline to follow through on sometimes mundane tasks associated with work or school.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-and-self-care-considerations">Physiological and Self-Care Considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-and-self-care-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In addition to suicidal and self-harm behavior, clients may engage in binging (excessive overeating) and purging (self-induced vomiting),</p>
<p>substance abuse, unprotected sex, or reckless behavior such as driving while intoxicated. They usually have difficulty sleeping.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="data-analysis">Data Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#data-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nursing diagnoses for clients with BPD may include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Risk for suicide</li>
<li>Risk for self-mutilation</li>
<li>Risk for other-directed violence</li>
<li>Ineffective coping</li>
<li>Social isolation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-vignette-borderline-personality-disorder">CLINICAL VIGNETTE: Borderline Personality Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-vignette-borderline-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sally had been calling her therapist all day, ever since their session this morning. But the therapist hadn't called her back, even though all her messages said this was an emergency. She was sure her therapist was angry at her and was probably going to drop her as a client. Then she'd have no one; she'd be abandoned by the only person in the world she could talk to. Sally was upset and crying as she began to run the razor blade across her arm. As the blood trickled out, she began to calm down. Then her therapist called and asked what the problem was. Sally was sobbing as she told her therapist that she was cutting her arm because the therapist didn't care anymore, that she was abandoning Sally just like everyone else in her life—her parents, her best friend, every man she had a relationship with. No one was ever there for her when she needed them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-care-plan-personality-disorder">NURSING CARE PLAN: PERSONALITY DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-personality-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Risk for Self-Mutilation:</strong> Behaviors that indicate potential for deliberate physical damage to self that is not intended to be fatal</p>
<p>778</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="risk-factors">RISK FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risk-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Impulsive displays of temper</li>
<li>Inability to express feelings verbally
Physically self-damaging acts</li>
<li>Attention-seeking behavior</li>
<li>Ineffective coping skills</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="expected-outcomes">EXPECTED OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immediate">Immediate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immediate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Be safe and free from injury throughout hospitalization.</li>
<li>Refrain from harming others or destroying property throughout hospitalization.</li>
<li>Respond to external limits within 24 to 48 hours.</li>
<li>Participate in treatment plan; for example, talk with staff or participate in group activities for at least 30 minutes twice a day within 24 to 48 hours.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stabilization">Stabilization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stabilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Eliminate acting-out behaviors (temper tantrums, self-harm, suicidal threats).</li>
<li>Develop a schedule or daily routine that includes socialization and daily responsibilities.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="community">Community<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Independently control urges for self-harming behavior.</li>
<li>Demonstrate alternative ways of expressing feelings, such as contact with a therapist or significant other.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="implementation">IMPLEMENTATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#implementation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Nursing Interventions*</th><th>Rationale</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>In your initial assessment, find out if he or she has any history of suicidal</td><td>The client's physical safety is a priority. <table><thead><tr><th>plans.</th><th>at risk for suicide.
