<p>Evaluate your feelings, beliefs, and attitudes regarding clients with somatic symptom disorders.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the early 1800s, the medical field began to consider the various social and psychological factors that influence illness. The term <strong>psychosomatic</strong> began to be used to convey the connection between the mind (<em>psyche</em>) and the body (<em>soma</em>) in states of health and illness. Essentially, the mind can cause the body either to create physical symptoms or to worsen physical illnesses. Real symptoms can begin, continue, or be worsened as a result of emotional factors. Examples include diabetes, hypertension, and colitis, all of which are medical illnesses influenced by stress and emotions. When a person is under a lot of stress or is not coping well with stress, symptoms of these medical illnesses worsen. In addition, stress can cause physical symptoms unrelated to a diagnosed medical illness. After a stressful day at work, many people experience “tension headaches” that can be quite painful. The headaches are a manifestation of stress rather than a symptom of an underlying medical problem.</p>
<p>The term <strong>hysteria</strong> refers to multiple physical complaints with no organic basis; the complaints are usually described dramatically. The concept of hysteria is believed to have originated in Egypt and is about 4,000 years old. In the Middle Ages, hysteria was associated with witchcraft, demons, and sorcerers. People with hysteria, usually women, were considered evil or possessed by evil spirits. Paul Briquet and Jean-Martin Charcot, both French physicians, identified hysteria as a disorder of the nervous system.</p>
<p>910</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-6a3a6224.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="somatic-symptom-illnesses">Somatic symptom illnesses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somatic-symptom-illnesses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Sigmund Freud, working with Charcot, observed that people with hysteria improved with hypnosis and experienced relief from their physical symptoms when they recalled memories and expressed emotions. This development led Freud to propose that people can convert unexpressed emotions into physical symptoms, a process now referred to as somatization (Esobar &amp; Dimsdale, 2017). This chapter discusses somatic symptom illnesses, or somatoform disorders, which are based on the concept of somatization.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="overview-of-somatic-symptom-illnesses">OVERVIEW OF SOMATIC SYMPTOM ILLNESSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview-of-somatic-symptom-illnesses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Somatization is defined as the transference of mental experiences and states</p>
<p>into bodily symptoms. Somatic symptom illnesses can be characterized as the presence of physical symptoms that suggest a medical condition without a demonstrable organic basis to account fully for them. The three central features of somatic symptom illnesses are as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>Physical complaints suggest major medical illness but have no demonstrable organic basis.</li>
<li>Psychological factors and conflicts seem important in initiating, exacerbating, and maintaining the symptoms.</li>
<li>Symptoms or magnified health concerns are not under the client’s conscious control.</li>
</ul>
<p>Clients are convinced they harbor serious physical problems despite negative results during diagnostic testing. They actually experience these physical symptoms as well as the accompanying pain, distress, and functional limitations such symptoms induce. Clients do not willfully control the physical symptoms. Although their illnesses are psychiatric in nature, many clients do not seek help from mental health professionals. Unfortunately, many health care professionals who do not understand the nature of somatic symptom illnesses are not sympathetic to these clients’ complaints (Black &amp; Andreasen, 2016). Nurses must remember that these clients really experience the symptoms they describe and cannot voluntarily control them.</p>
<p>Somatic symptom disorders include (Esobar &amp; Dimsdale, 2017):</p>
<ul>
<li>Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by one or more physical symptoms that have no organic basis. Individuals spend a lot of time and energy focused on health concerns, often believe symptoms to be indicative of serious illness, and experience significant distress and anxiety about their health.</li>
<li>Conversion disorder, sometimes called conversion reaction, involves unexplained, usually sudden deficits in sensory or motor function (e.g., blindness, paralysis). These deficits suggest a neurologic disorder but are associated with psychological factors. There is usually significant functional impairment. There may be an attitude of <em>la belle indifférence</em>, a seeming lack of concern or distress, about the functional loss.</li>
<li>Pain disorder has the primary physical symptom of pain, which is generally unrelieved by analgesics and greatly affected by psychological factors in terms of onset, severity, exacerbation, and maintenance.</li>
<li>Illness anxiety disorder, formerly hypochondriasis, is preoccupation with the fear that one has a serious disease (<em>disease conviction</em>) or will get a serious disease (<em>disease phobia</em>). It is thought that clients with this disorder misinterpret bodily sensations or functions.</li>
</ul>
<p>912</p>
<p>Somatic symptom illnesses are more common in women than in men; they may represent about 5% to 7% of the general population, but estimates can vary greatly. Because most people with illness anxiety are seen in general medical or family practice settings, it is difficult to make accurate estimates of occurrence. Reports of pain are one of the most common complaints in medical practice, and it is difficult to distinguish physical from psychological causation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="onset-and-clinical-course">Onset and Clinical Course<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#onset-and-clinical-course" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients with somatic symptom disorder often experience symptoms in adolescence, though these diagnoses may not be made until early adulthood (about 25 years of age). Conversion disorder usually occurs between the ages of 10 and 35 years. Pain disorder and illness anxiety disorder can occur at any age.</p>
<p>All somatic symptom illnesses are either chronic or recurrent, lasting for decades for many people. Clients with somatic symptom illness and conversion disorder most likely seek help from mental health professionals after they have exhausted efforts at finding a diagnosed medical condition. Clients with illness anxiety, or pain disorder, are unlikely to receive treatment in mental health settings unless they have a comorbid condition. Clients with somatic symptom illnesses tend to go from one physician or clinic to another, or they may see multiple providers at once in an effort to obtain relief of symptoms. They tend to be pessimistic about the medical establishment and often believe their disease could be diagnosed if providers were more competent.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-vignette-conversion-disorder">CLINICAL VIGNETTE: Conversion Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-vignette-conversion-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Matthew, 13 years old, has just been transferred from a medical unit to the adolescent psychiatric unit. He had been on the medical unit for 3 days, undergoing extensive tests to determine the cause of a sudden onset of blindness. No organic pathology was discovered, and Matthew was diagnosed with a conversion disorder.</p>
<p>As the nurse interviews Matthew, she notices that he is calm and speaks of his inability to see in a matter-of-fact manner, demonstrating no distress at his blindness. Matthew seems to have the usual interests of a 13-year-</p>
<p>old, describing his activities at school and with his friends. However, the nurse finds that Matthew has little to say about his parents, his younger brother, or activities at home.</p>
<p>Later, the nurse has a chance to talk with Matthew’s mother when she comes to the unit after work. Soon, Matthew’s mother is crying, telling the nurse that her husband has a drinking problem and has been increasingly violent at home. She admitted that 2 days before Matthew’s symptoms developed, Matthew witnessed one of his father’s rages, which included breaking furniture and hitting her. When Matthew tried to help his mother, his father called him spineless and worthless and told him to go to the basement and stay there. The nurse understands that the violence Matthew has witnessed and his inability to change the situation may be the triggering event for his conversion disorder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="related-disorders">Related Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#related-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Somatic symptom illnesses need to be distinguished from other body-related mental disorders such as malingering and factitious disorders, also known as fabricated or induced illness, in which people feign or intentionally produce symptoms for some purpose or gain. In malingering and factitious disorders, people willfully control the symptoms. In somatic symptom illnesses, clients do not voluntarily control their physical symptoms.</p>
<p>Malingering is the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms; it is motivated by external incentives such as avoiding work, evading criminal prosecution, obtaining financial compensation, or obtaining drugs. People who malinger have no real physical symptoms or grossly exaggerate relatively minor symptoms. Their purpose is some external incentive or outcome that they view as important and results directly from the illness. People who malinger can stop the physical symptoms as soon as they have gained what they wanted (Bass &amp; Wade, 2019).</p>
<p>Factitious disorder, imposed on self, occurs when a person intentionally produces or feigns physical or psychological symptoms solely to gain attention. People with factitious disorder may even inflict injury on themselves to receive attention. The common term for factitious disorder imposed on self is <strong>Munchausen syndrome</strong> (Quinn, Wang, Powsner, &amp; Eisendrath, 2017). A variation of factitious disorder, imposed on others, is commonly called <strong>Munchausen syndrome by proxy</strong>, and occurs when a</p>
<p>914</p>
<p>person inflicts illness or injury on someone else to gain the attention of emergency medical personnel or to be a “hero” for saving the victim. An example would be a nurse who gives excess intravenous potassium to a client and then “saves his life” by performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Although factitious disorders are uncommon, they occur most often in people who are in or are familiar with medical professions, such as nurses, physicians, medical technicians, or hospital volunteers. People who injure clients or their children through Munchausen syndrome by proxy generally are arrested and prosecuted in the legal system. Factitious disorders are also called fabricated or induced illnesses.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-a4f7344a.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg">
Munchausen syndrome by proxy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nursing-care-plan-conversion-disorder">NURSING CARE PLAN: CONVERSION DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-conversion-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ineffective Denial: Unsuccessful attempt to ignore or minimize reality of events or situations that are unpleasant to confront</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assessment-data">ASSESSMENT DATA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Presence of physical limitation or disability with indifference to or lack of concern about the severity of the symptom</li>
<li>Refusal to seek health care for the physical symptom</li>
<li>Lack of insight into stress, conflict, or problematic relationships</li>
<li>Difficulty with feelings of anger, hostility, or conflict</li>
<li>Decreased ability to express needs and feelings</li>
<li>Secondary gain related to the physical symptom or disability</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expected-outcomes">EXPECTED OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="immediate">Immediate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immediate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the conflict underlying the physical symptoms within 4 to 5 days.</li>
<li>Identify feelings of fear, anger, guilt, anxiety, or inadequacy within 4 to 5 days.</li>
<li>Verbalize steps of the problem-solving process within 4 to 5 days.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stabilization">Stabilization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stabilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Verbalize feelings of fear, anger, guilt, or inadequacy.</li>
<li>Verbalize knowledge of illness, including the concept of secondary gain.</li>
<li>Demonstrate use of the problem-solving process.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="community">Community<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Negotiate resolution of conflicts with family, friends, and significant others.</li>
</ul>
<p>917</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>IMPLEMENTATION</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Nursing Interventions</td><td>Rationale</td></tr><tr><td>Involve the client in the usual activities, self-care, eating in the dining room, and so on, as you would other clients.</td><td>Your expectation will enhance the client’s participation and will diminish secondary gain.</td></tr><tr><td>After medical evaluation of the symptom, withdraw attention from the client’s physical status except for necessary care. Avoid discussing the physical symptom; withdraw your attention from the client if necessary.</td><td>Lack of attention to expression of physical complaints will help minimize secondary gain and decrease the client’s focus from the symptom.</td></tr><tr><td>Expect the client to participate in activities as fully as possible. Make your expectations clear and do not give the client special privileges or excuse him or her from all expectations due to physical limitations.</td><td>Granting special privileges and excusing the client from responsibilities are forms of secondary gain. The client may need to become more uncomfortable to risk relinquishing the physical conversion as a coping strategy.</td></tr><tr><td>Do not argue with the client. Withdraw your attention if necessary.</td><td>Arguing with the client undermines limits. Withdrawing attention may be effective in diminishing secondary gain.</td></tr><tr><td>Focus interactions on the client’s feelings, home or work situations, and relationships.</td><td>Increased attention to emotional issues will help the client shift attention to these feelings.</td></tr><tr><td>Explore with the client his or her personal relationships and related feelings.</td><td>Conversion reaction symptoms are often related to interpersonal conflicts or situations. Talking about these things may help the client develop insight and additional coping mechanisms.</td></tr><tr><td>Teach the client and the family or significant others about conversion reaction, stress management, interpersonal dynamics, coping, and conflict resolution strategies.</td><td>The client and the family or significant others may have little or no knowledge of these areas. Increasing their knowledge can promote understanding, motivation for change, and support for the client.</td></tr><tr><td>Talk with the client about coping strategies he or she has used in the past that did not include physical symptoms.</td><td>The client may have used coping strategies in the past that did not result in physical symptoms, perhaps for issues or conflicts that were less stressful for the client. The client may be able to build on these strategies in the future.</td></tr><tr><td>Teach the client about stress management skills, such as increasing physical exercise, expressing feelings verbally or in a journal, or</td><td>The client may have limited or no knowledge of or may not have used stress management techniques in the past. If the client begins to</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>meditation techniques. Encourage the client to practice this type of technique while in the hospital.</th><th>build skills in the treatment setting, he or she can experience success and receive positive feedback.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Teach the client the problem-solving process: identify the problem, examine alternatives, weigh the pros and cons of each alternative, select and implement an approach, and evaluate its success.</td><td>The client may not know the steps of a logical, orderly process to solve problems. Such a process can be helpful to the client in dealing with stressful situations in the future.</td></tr><tr><td>Praise the client when he or she is able to discuss the physical symptom as a method used to cope with conflict.</td><td>Positive feedback can reinforce the client's insight and help the client recognize physical symptoms as related to emotional issues in the future.</td></tr><tr><td>Give the client positive feedback for expressing feeling and trying conflict resolution strategies.</td><td>Positive feedback can increase desired behavior and help the client build confidence in preparation for discharge.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Collaborative interventions.</p>
<p>Medically unexplained symptoms (MUS) and functional somatic syndromes are terms used more frequently in general medical setting. They refer to physical symptoms and limitations of function that has no medical diagnoses to explain their existence. There is overlap between these terms and somatic disorders diagnosed in mental health settings (Esobar &amp; Dimsdale, 2017). MUS is often more acceptable to the patient because it doesn't have the connotation of "it's all in your head" as do psychosomatic descriptors. Many patients are seen by general practitioners and are not involved in mental health settings. Effective treatment from patients' perspectives includes being listened to and heard regarding symptoms, learning to cope with symptoms and limitations, learning to ignore some symptoms when possible, and positive response and support from providers (Sowinska &amp; Czachowski, 2018).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="etiology">ETIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="psychosocial-theories">Psychosocial Theories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#psychosocial-theories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Psychosocial theorists believe that people with somatic symptom illnesses keep stress, anxiety, or frustration inside rather than expressing them outwardly. This is called internalization. Clients express these internalized feelings and stress through physical symptoms (somatization). Both</p>
<p>internalization and somatization are unconscious defense mechanisms. Clients are not consciously aware of the process, and they do not voluntarily control it.</p>
<p>People with somatic symptom illnesses do not readily and directly express their feelings and emotions verbally. Some experience alexithymia, or the inability to identify emotions. This is different than an unwillingness or refusal to identify emotions. They have tremendous difficulty dealing with interpersonal conflict. When placed in situations involving conflict or emotional stress, their physical symptoms appear to worsen. The worsening of physical symptoms helps them meet psychological needs for security, attention, and affection through primary and secondary gain. Primary gains are the direct internal benefits that being sick provides, such as relief of anxiety, conflict, or distress. Secondary gains are the external or personal benefits received from others because one is sick, such as attention from family members and comfort measures (e.g., being brought tea, receiving a back rub). The person soon learns that he or she "needs to be sick" to have his or her emotional needs met.</p>
<p>Somatization is associated most often with women, as evidenced by the old term hysteria (Greek for "wandering uterus"). Ancient theorists believed that unexplained female pains resulted from migration of the uterus throughout the woman's body. Psychosocial theorists posit that increased incidence of somatization in women may be related to various factors:</p>
<ul>
<li>Boys in the United States are taught to be stoic and to "take it like a man," causing them to offer fewer physical complaints as adults.</li>
<li>Women seek medical treatment more often than men, and it is more socially acceptable for them to do so.</li>
<li>Childhood sexual abuse, which is related to somatization, happens more frequently to girls.</li>
<li>Women more often receive treatment for psychiatric disorders with strong somatic components such as depression.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biologic-theories">Biologic Theories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biologic-theories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Research has shown differences in the way clients with somatoform disorders regulate and interpret stimuli. These clients cannot sort relevant from irrelevant stimuli and respond equally to both types. In other words, they may experience a normal body sensation such as peristalsis and attach a pathologic rather than a normal meaning to it. Too little inhibition of sensory input amplifies awareness of physical symptoms and exaggerates response to bodily</p>
<p>919</p>
<p>sensations. For example, minor discomfort such as muscle tightness becomes amplified because of the client's concern and attention to the tightness. This amplified sensory awareness causes the person to experience somatic sensations as more intense, noxious, and disturbing (Black &amp; Andreasen, 2016). Research has shown that visceral hypersensitivity is associated with the severity of gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms in large cohorts of patients with functional GI disorders in a variety of settings (Simren et al., 2018).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cultural-considerations">CULTURAL CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cultural-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The type and frequency of somatic symptoms and their meaning may vary across cultures. Pseudoneurologic symptoms of somatization disorder in Africa and South Asia include burning hands and feet and the nondelusional sensation of worms in the head or ants under the skin. Symptoms related to male reproduction are more common in some countries or cultures—for example, men in India often have dhat, which is a hypochondriacal concern about loss of semen. Somatic symptom disorder is rare in men in the United States but more common in Greece and Puerto Rico.</p>
<p>Many cultural concepts of distress have corresponding somatic symptoms not explained by a medical condition (Table 21.1). Koro occurs in Southeast Asia and may be related to body dysmorphic disorder. It is characterized by the belief that the penis is shrinking and will disappear into the abdomen, causing the man to die. Falling-out episodes, found in the southern United States and the Caribbean islands, are characterized by a sudden collapse during which the person cannot see or move. Hwa-Byung is a Korean folk syndrome attributed to the suppression of anger and includes insomnia, fatigue, panic, indigestion, and generalized aches and pains. Sangue dormido (sleeping blood) occurs among Portuguese Cape Verde Islanders who report pain, numbness, tremors, paralysis, seizures, blindness, heart attacks, and miscarriages. Shenjing shuairuo occurs in China and includes physical and mental fatigue, dizziness, headache, pain, sleep disturbance, memory loss, GI problems, and sexual dysfunction (Lewis-Fernandez, Kirmayer, Guarnaccia, &amp; Ruiz, 2017).</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Syndrome</th><th>Culture</th><th>Characteristics</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Dhat</td><td>India</td><td>Hypochondriacal concern about semen loss</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>Koro</th><th>Southeast Asia</th><th>Belief that penis is shrinking and will disappear into abdomen, resulting in death</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Falling-out episodes</td><td>Southern United States, Caribbean islands</td><td>Sudden collapse; person cannot see or move</td></tr><tr><td>Hwa-Byung</td><td>Korea</td><td>Suppressed anger causes insomnia, fatigue, panic, indigestion, and generalized aches and pains</td></tr><tr><td>Sangue dormido (sleeping blood)</td><td>Portuguese Cape Verde Islands</td><td>Pain, numbness, tremors, paralysis, seizures, blindness, heart attack, miscarriage</td></tr><tr><td>Shenjing shuairuo</td><td>China</td><td>Physical and mental fatigue, dizziness, headache, pain, sleep disturbance, memory loss, gastrointestinal problems, sexual dysfunction</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Adapted from Lewis-Fernandez, R., Kirmayer, L. J., Guarnaccia, P. J., &amp; Ruiz, P. (2017). Cultural concepts of distress. In B. J. Sadock, V. A. Sadock, &amp; P. Ruiz (Eds.), Comprehensive textbook of psychiatry (Vol. 2, 10th ed., pp. 2443-2460). Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams &amp; Wilkins/Wolters Kluwer.</p>
<p>The presence of a host of somatic symptoms can also be associated with other diagnoses. Zhao and colleagues (2018) found that patients in China diagnosed with major depression sought treatment in various medical settings. They reported experiencing insomnia, weight loss, low appetite, circulatory system complaints, headache, hyposexuality, GI complaints, and respiratory system problems.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="treatment">TREATMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and improving quality of life. The health care provider must show empathy and sensitivity to the client's physical complaints. A trusting relationship helps ensure clients stay with and receive care from one provider instead of "doctor shopping."</p>
<p>For many clients, depression and anxiety may accompany or result from somatic symptom illnesses. Thus, antidepressants help in some cases (Strohle, Gensichen, &amp; Domschke, 2018). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft), and paroxetine (Paxil) are most commonly used (Table 21.2).</p>
<p>TABLE 21.2
Antidepressants Used to Treat Somatic Symptom
Illnesses</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Drug</th><th>Usual Dose (mg/day)</th><th>Nursing Considerations</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Fluoxetine (Prozac)</td><td>20–60</td><td>Monitor for rash, hives, insomnia, headache, anxiety, drowsiness, nausea, loss of appetite; avoid alcohol</td></tr><tr><td>Paroxetine (Paxil)</td><td>20–60</td><td>Monitor for nausea, loss of appetite, dizziness, dry mouth, somnolence or insomnia, sweating, sexual dysfunction; avoid alcohol</td></tr><tr><td>Sertraline (Zoloft)</td><td>50–200</td><td>Monitor for nausea, loss of appetite, diarrhea, headache, insomnia, sexual dysfunction; avoid alcohol</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>For clients with pain disorder, referral to a chronic pain clinic may be useful. Clients learn methods of pain management, such as visual imaging and relaxation. Services such as physical therapy to maintain and build muscle tone help improve functional abilities. Providers should avoid prescribing and administering narcotic analgesics to these clients because of the risk for dependence or abuse. Clients can use nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents to help reduce pain.</p>
<p>Involvement in therapy groups is beneficial for some people with somatic symptom illnesses. Clients with somatic symptom disorder and anxiety illness disorder who participated in a structured cognitive-behavioral group showed evidence of improved physical and emotional health. The overall goals of the group were offering peer support, sharing methods of coping, and perceiving and expressing emotions. Clients with hypochondriasis who were willing to participate in cognitive-behavioral therapy and take medications were able to alter their erroneous perceptions of threat (of illness) and improve. Cognitive-behavioral therapy also produced significant improvement in clients with somatic symptom disorder (Hedman, Axelsson, Anderson, Lekander, &amp; Ljotsson, 2016).</p>
<p>Education or providing information has also been effective for clients with somatic illness or symptoms. Reading both internet-based educational material and books were other effective therapies (Hedman et al., 2016).</p>
<p>In terms of prognosis, somatic symptom illnesses tend to be chronic or recurrent. With treatment, conversion disorder often remits in a few weeks but recurs in 25% of clients. Somatic symptom disorder, illness anxiety disorder, and pain disorder often last for many years, and clients report being in poor health (Black &amp; Andreasen, 2016).</p>
<p>922</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="application-of-the-nursing-process">APPLICATION OF THE NURSING PROCESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#application-of-the-nursing-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The underlying mechanism of somatization is consistent for clients with somatoform disorders of all types. This section discusses application of the nursing process for clients with somatization; differences among the disorders are highlighted in the appropriate places.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assessment">Assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nurse must investigate physical health status thoroughly to ensure there is no underlying pathology requiring treatment. Box 21.1 contains a useful screening test for somatic symptom severity. When a client has been diagnosed with a somatic symptom illness, it is important not to dismiss all future complaints because, at any time, the client could develop a physical condition that would require medical attention.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-21-1-assessment-for-somatic-symptom-severity">BOX 21.1 Assessment for Somatic Symptom Severity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-21-1-assessment-for-somatic-symptom-severity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For the past 4 weeks, each of the following symptoms is rated as:</p>
<p>Not bothered at all
Bothered a little
Bothered a lot</p>
<ol>
<li>Stomach pain</li>
<li>Back pain</li>
<li>Pain in arms, legs, and joints</li>
<li>Menstrual cramps or other problems with periods (females only)</li>
<li>Headaches</li>
<li>Chest pain</li>
<li>Dizziness</li>
<li>Fainting spells</li>
<li>Feeling your heart race or pound</li>
<li>Shortness of breath</li>
<li>Pain or problems during sexual intercourse</li>
</ol>
<p>923</p>
<ol start="12">
<li>Constipation, loose stools, or diarrhea</li>
<li>Nausea, gas, or indigestion</li>
<li>Feeling tired or having low energy</li>
<li>Trouble sleeping</li>
</ol>
<p>Score by: Not bothered at all = 0
Bothered a little = 1
Bothered a lot = 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">History<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients usually provide a lengthy and detailed account of previous physical problems, numerous diagnostic tests, and perhaps even a number of surgical procedures. It is likely that they have seen multiple health care providers over several years. Clients may express dismay or anger at the medical community with comments such as “They just can’t find out what’s wrong with me” or “They’re all incompetent, and they’re trying to tell me I’m crazy!” The exception may be clients with conversion disorder, who show little emotion when describing physical limitations or lack of a medical diagnosis (la belle indifférence).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-appearance-and-motor-behavior">General Appearance and Motor Behavior<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-appearance-and-motor-behavior" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Overall appearance is usually not remarkable. Often, clients walk slowly or with an unusual gait because of the pain or disability caused by the symptoms. They may exhibit a facial expression of discomfort or physical distress. In many cases, they brighten and look much better as the assessment interview begins because they have the nurse’s undivided attention. Clients with somatization disorder usually describe their complaints in colorful, exaggerated terms, but often lack specific information.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mood-and-affect">Mood and Affect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mood-and-affect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mood is often labile, shifting from seeming depressed and sad when describing physical problems to looking bright and excited when talking about how they had to go to the hospital in the middle of the night by ambulance. Emotions are often exaggerated, as are reports of physical symptoms. Clients describing a series of personal crises related to their physical health may appear pleased rather than distressed about these situations. Clients with conversion disorder display an unexpected lack of</p>
<p>924</p>
<p>distress.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thought-process-and-content">Thought Process and Content<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thought-process-and-content" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients who somatize do not experience disordered thought processes. The content of their thinking is primarily about often exaggerated physical concerns; for example, when they have a simple cold, they may be convinced it is pneumonia. They may even talk about dying and what music they want played at their funeral.</p>
<p>Clients are unlikely to be able to think about or respond to questions about emotional feelings. They will answer questions about how they feel in terms of physical health or sensations. For example, the nurse may ask, “How did you feel about having to quit your job?” The client might respond, “Well, I thought I’d feel better with the extra rest, but my back pain was just as bad as ever.”</p>
<p>Clients with illness anxiety disorder focus on the fear of serious illness rather than the existence of illness, as seen in clients with other somatoform disorders. However, they are just as preoccupied with physical concerns as other somatizing clients and are likewise limited in their abilities to identify emotional feelings or interpersonal issues. Clients with hypochondriasis are preoccupied with bodily functions, ruminate about illness, are fascinated with medical information, and have unrealistic fears about potential infection and prescription medication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sensorium-and-intellectual-processes">Sensorium and Intellectual Processes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensorium-and-intellectual-processes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients are alert and oriented. Intellectual functions are unimpaired.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="judgment-and-insight">Judgment and Insight<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#judgment-and-insight" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Exaggerated responses to their physical health may affect clients’ judgment. They have little or no insight into their behavior. They are firmly convinced their problem is entirely physical and often believe others don’t understand.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="self-concept">Self-Concept<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-concept" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients focus only on the physical part of themselves. They are unlikely to think about personal characteristics or strengths and are uncomfortable when asked to do so. Clients who somatize have low self-esteem and seem to deal with it by totally focusing on physical concerns. They lack confidence, have little success in work situations, and have difficulty managing daily life issues, which they relate solely to their physical status.</p>
<p>925</p>
<p>926</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-vignette-illness-anxiety-disorder">CLINICAL VIGNETTE: Illness Anxiety Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-vignette-illness-anxiety-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Maude is a 75-year-old, widowed, retired teacher who is admitted for illness anxiety disorder. For the past 18 months, Maude has been evaluated repeatedly by several internists and GI specialists for persistent symptoms of abdominal pain, indigestion, heartburn, and nausea. She is convinced she has cancer of the stomach, even though all test results fail to show any pathology. Despite repeated reassurances from physicians that she is healthy, Maude believes the physicians and clinics are incompetent and thinks her normal lab tests are incorrect. Maude's husband died 2 years ago, and her physical complaints and insistence about having cancer have become markedly worse since then.</p>
<p>In the hospital setting, Maude fumes that she is not a crazy person and denies having any emotional problems. Her grown children report that she has not grieved following their father's death but rather became completely preoccupied with her own health. Maude thinks her children are uncaring and don't want to be bothered with her. She has agreed to this hospitalization just to "prove they don't know what they're talking about."</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nursing-care-plan-hypochondriasis-illness-anxiety-disorder">NURSING CARE PLAN: HYPOCHONDRIASIS/ILLNESS ANXIETY DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-hypochondriasis-illness-anxiety-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Ineffective Coping:</strong> Inability to form a valid appraisal of the stressors, inadequate choices of practiced responses, and/or inability to use available resources</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assessment-data">ASSESSMENT DATA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Denial of emotional problems</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Difficulty identifying and expressing feelings</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of insight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Self-preoccupation, especially with physical functioning</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fears of or rumination on disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Numerous somatic complaints (may involve many different organs or systems)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sensory complaints (pain, loss of taste sensation, olfactory complaints)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reluctance or refusal to participate in psychiatric treatment program or activities</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reliance on medications or physical treatments (such as laxative dependence)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extensive use of over-the-counter medications, home remedies, enemas, and so forth</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ritualistic behaviors (such as exaggerated bowel routines)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tremors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Limited gratification from interpersonal relationships</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of emotional support system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anxiety</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Secondary gains received for physical problems</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of repeated visits to physicians or hospital admissions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of repeated medical evaluations with no findings of abnormalities</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expected-outcomes">EXPECTED OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="immediate">Immediate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immediate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="the-client-will">The client will<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-client-will" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Participate in the treatment program; for example, talk with staff for 15 minutes or participate in a group activity at least twice a day within 24 to 48 hours.</li>
<li>Demonstrate decreased physical complaints within 2 to 3 days.</li>
<li>Demonstrate compliance with medical therapy and medications within 2 to 3 days.</li>
<li>Demonstrate adequate energy, food, and fluid intake; for example, eat at least 50% of each meal within 3 to 4 days.</li>
<li>Identify life stresses and anxieties within 2 to 3 days.</li>
<li>Identify the relationship between stress and physical symptoms within 4 to 5 days.</li>
<li>Express feelings verbally within 3 to 4 days.</li>
<li>Identify alternative ways to deal with stress, anxiety, or other</li>
</ul>
<p>927</p>
<p>feelings; for example, talking with others, physical activity, keeping a journal, and so forth within 4 to 5 days.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stabilization">Stabilization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stabilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Demonstrate decreased ritualistic behaviors.</li>
<li>Demonstrate decreased physical attention-seeking complaints.</li>
<li>Verbalize increased insight into the dynamics of hypochondriacal behavior, including secondary gains.</li>
<li>Verbalize an understanding of therapeutic regimens and medications, if any.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="community">Community<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Eliminate overuse of medications or physical treatments.</li>
<li>Demonstrate alternative ways to deal with stress, anxiety, or other feelings.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="implementation">IMPLEMENTATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#implementation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Nursing Interventions</th><th>Rationale</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>The initial nursing assessment should include a complete physical assessment, a history of previous complaints and treatment, and a consideration of each current complaint.</td><td>The nursing assessment provides a baseline from which to begin planning care.</td></tr><tr><td>The nursing staff should note the medical staff’s assessment of each complaint on the client’s admission.</td><td>Genuine physical problems must be noted and treated.</td></tr><tr><td>Each time the client voices a new complaint, the client should be referred to the medical staff for assessment (and treatment if appropriate).</td><td>It is unsafe to assume that all physical complaints are hypochondriacal; the client could really be ill or injured. The client may attempt to establish the legitimacy of complaints by being genuinely injured or ill.</td></tr><tr><td>Work with the medical staff to limit the number, variety, strength, and frequency of medications, enemas, and so forth that are made available to the client.</td><td>A team effort helps prevent the client’s manipulation of staff members to obtain additional medication.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>When the client requests a medication or treatment, encourage the client to identify what precipitated his or her complaint and deal with it in other ways.</th><th>If the client can obtain stress relief in a nonchemical, nonmedical way, he or she is less likely to use the medication or treatment.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Observe and record the circumstances related to complaints; talk about your observations with the client.</td><td>Alerting the client to situations surrounding the complaint helps him or her see the relatedness of stress and physical symptoms.</td></tr><tr><td>Help the client identify and use nonchemical methods of pain relief, such as relaxation.</td><td>Using nonchemical pain relief shifts the focus of coping away from medications and increases the client's sense of control.</td></tr><tr><td>Minimize the amount of time and attention given to complaints. When the client makes a complaint, refer him or her to the medical staff (if it is a new complaint) or follow the team treatment plan. Then tell the client you will discuss something else, but not bodily complaints. Tell the client you are interested in the client as a person, not just in his or her physical complaints. If the complaint is not acute, ask the client to discuss the complaint during a regular appointment with the medical staff.</td><td>If physical complaints are unsuccessful in gaining attention, they should decrease in frequency over time.</td></tr><tr><td>Withdraw your attention if the client insists on making complaints the sole topic of conversation. Tell the client your reason for withdrawal and that you will return later to discuss other topics.</td><td>It is important to make clear to the client that attention is withdrawn from physical complaints, not from the client as a person.</td></tr><tr><td>Allow the client a specific time limit (like 5 minutes/hour) to discuss physical complaints with one person. The remaining staff will discuss only other issues with the client.</td><td>Because physical complaints have been the client's primary coping strategy, it is less threatening to the client if you limit this behavior initially rather than forbid it. If the client is denied this coping mechanism before new skills can be developed, hypochondriacal behavior may increase.</td></tr><tr><td>Acknowledge the complaint as the client's perception and then follow the previous approaches; do not argue about the somatic complaints.</td><td>Arguing gives the client's complaints attention, albeit negative, and the client is able to avoid discussing feelings.</td></tr><tr><td>Use minimal objective reassurance in conjunction with</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>questions to explore the client’s feelings. (“Your tests have shown that you have no lesions. Do you still feel that you do? What are your feelings about this?”)</th><th>make the transition to discussing feelings.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Initially, carefully assess the client’s self-image, social patterns, and ways of dealing with anger, stress, and so forth.</td><td>This assessment provides a knowledge base regarding hypochondriacal behaviors.</td></tr><tr><td>Talk with the client about sources of satisfaction and dissatisfaction, relationships, employment, and so forth.</td><td>Open-ended discussion is usually nonthreatening and helps the client begin self-assessment.</td></tr><tr><td>After some discussion of the above and developing a trust relationship, talk more directly with the client and encourage him or her to identify specific stresses, recent and ongoing.</td><td>The client’s perception of stressors forms the basis of his or her behavior and is usually more significant than others’ perception of those stressors.</td></tr><tr><td>If the client is using denial as a defense mechanism, point out apparent or possible stresses (in a nonthreatening way) and ask the client for feedback.</td><td>If the client is in denial, more direct approaches may produce anger or hostility and threaten the trust relationship.</td></tr><tr><td>Gradually, help the client identify possible connections between anxiety and the occurrence of physical symptoms. What makes the client more or less comfortable? What is the client doing, or what is going on around the client when he or she experiences symptoms?</td><td>The client can begin to see the relatedness of stress and physical problems at his or her own pace. Self-realization will be more acceptable to the client than the nurse telling the client the problem.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to discuss his or her feelings about the fears rather than the fears themselves.</td><td>The focus is on feelings of fear, not fear of physical problems.</td></tr><tr><td>Explore the client’s feelings of lack of control over stress and life events.</td><td>The client may have helpless feelings but may not recognize this independently.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to keep a diary of situations, stresses, and occurrence of symptoms and use it to identify relationships between stresses and symptoms.</td><td>Reflecting on written items may be more accurate and less threatening to the client.</td></tr><tr><td>Talk with the client at least once per shift, focusing on the client identifying and expressing feelings.</td><td>Demonstrating consistent interest in the client facilitates the relationship and can desensitize the discussion of emotional issues.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>930</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Encourage the client to ventilate feelings by talking or crying, through physical activities, and so forth.</th><th>The client may have difficulty expressing feelings directly. Your support may help him or her develop these skills.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Encourage the client to express feelings directly, especially feelings with which the client is uncomfortable (such as anger or resentment).</td><td>Direct expression of feelings will minimize the need to use physical symptoms to express them.</td></tr><tr><td>Notice the client’s interactions with others and give positive feedback for self-assertion and expressing feelings, especially anger, resentment, and other so-called negative emotions.</td><td>The client needs to know that appropriate expressions of anger or other negative emotions are acceptable and that he or she can feel better physically as a result of these expressions.</td></tr><tr><td>Teach the client and his or her family or significant others about the dynamics of hypochondriacal behavior and the treatment plan, including plans after discharge.</td><td>The client and his or her family or significant others may have little or no knowledge of these areas. Knowledge of the treatment plan will promote long-term behavior change.</td></tr><tr><td>Talk with the client and significant others about secondary gains, and together develop a plan to reduce those gains. Identify the needs the client is attempting to meet with secondary gains (such as attention or escape from responsibilities).</td><td>Maintaining limits to reduce secondary gain requires everyone’s participation to be successful. The client’s family and significant others must be aware of the client’s needs if they want to be effective in helping to meet those needs.</td></tr><tr><td>Help the client plan to meet his or her needs in more direct ways. Show the client he or she can gain attention when he or she does not exhibit symptoms, deals with responsibilities directly, or asserts him or herself in the face of stress.</td><td>Positive feedback and support for healthier behavior tend to make that behavior recur more frequently. The client’s family and significant others must also use positive reinforcement.</td></tr><tr><td>Reduce the benefits of illness as much as possible. Do not allow the client to avoid responsibilities or allow special privileges, such as staying in bed by voicing somatic discomfort.</td><td>If physical problems do not get the client what he or she wants, the client is less likely to cope in that manner.</td></tr><tr><td>Teach the client more healthful daily living habits, including diet, stress management techniques, daily exercise, rest, possible connection between caffeine and</td><td>Optimal physical wellness is especially important with clients using physical symptoms as a</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>931</p>
<p>932</p>
<p><em>Collaborative interventions.</em></p>
<p>Adapted from Schultz, J. M., &amp; Videbeck, S. L. (2013). <em>Lippincott’s manual of psychiatric nursing care plans</em> (9th ed.). Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams &amp; Wilkins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="roles-and-relationships">Roles and Relationships<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#roles-and-relationships" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients are unlikely to be employed, though they may have a past work history. They often lose jobs because of excessive absenteeism or inability to perform work; clients may have quit working voluntarily because of poor physical health. Consumed with seeking medical care, they have difficulty fulfilling family roles. It is likely that these clients have few friends and spend little time in social activities. They may decline to see friends or go out socially for fear that they would become desperately ill away from home. Most socialization takes place with members of the health care community.</p>
<p>Clients may report a lack of family support and understanding. Family members may tire of the ceaseless complaints and the client’s refusal to accept the absence of a medical diagnosis. The illnesses and physical conditions often interfere with planned family events, such as going on vacations or attending family gatherings. Home life is often chaotic and unpredictable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-and-self-care-concerns">Physiological and Self-Care Concerns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-and-self-care-concerns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In addition to the multitude of physical complaints, these clients often have legitimate needs in terms of their health practices (Box 21.2). Clients who somatize often have sleep pattern disturbances, lack basic nutrition, and get no exercise. In addition, they may be taking multiple prescriptions for pain or other complaints. If a client has been using anxiolytics or medications for pain, the nurse must consider the possibility of withdrawal (see Chapter 19).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-21-2-clinical-nurse-alert">BOX 21.2 Clinical Nurse Alert<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-21-2-clinical-nurse-alert" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Just because a client has been diagnosed with a somatic symptom illness, do not automatically dismiss all future complaints. He or she should be completely assessed because the client could at any time develop a physical condition requiring medical attention.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="data-analysis">Data Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#data-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Nursing diagnoses commonly used when working with clients who somatize include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ineffective coping</li>
<li>Ineffective denial</li>
<li>Impaired social interaction
Anxiety
Disturbed sleep pattern
Fatigue
Pain</li>
</ul>
<p>Clients with conversion disorder may be at risk for disuse syndrome from having pseudoneurologic paralysis symptoms. In other words, if clients do not use a limb for a long time, the muscles may weaken or undergo atrophy from lack of use.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="outcome-identification">Outcome Identification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#outcome-identification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Treatment outcomes for clients with a somatic symptom illness may include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The client will identify the relationship between stress and physical symptoms.</li>
<li>The client will verbally express emotional feelings.</li>
<li>The client will follow an established daily routine.</li>
<li>The client will demonstrate alternative ways to deal with stress, anxiety, and other feelings.</li>
<li>The client will demonstrate healthier behaviors regarding rest, activity, and nutritional intake.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intervention">Intervention<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intervention" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="providing-health-teaching">Providing Health Teaching<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#providing-health-teaching" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nurse must help the client learn how to establish a daily routine that includes improved health behaviors. Adequate nutritional intake, improved sleep patterns, and a realistic balance of activity and rest are all areas with which the client may need assistance. The nurse should expect resistance, including protests from the client that he or she does not feel well enough to do these things. The challenge for the nurse is to validate the client's feelings while encouraging him or her to participate in</p>
<p>activities.</p>
<p><strong>Nurse:</strong> "Let's take a walk outside for some fresh air." (encouraging collaboration)</p>
<p><strong>Client:</strong> "I wish I could, but I feel so terrible, I just can't do it."</p>
<p><strong>Nurse:</strong> "I know this is difficult, but some exercise is essential. It will be a short walk." (validation; encouraging collaboration)</p>
<p>The nurse can use a similar approach to gain client participation in eating more nutritious foods, getting up and dressed at a certain time every morning, and setting a regular bedtime. The nurse can also explain that inactivity and poor eating habits perpetuate discomfort and that it is often necessary to engage in behaviors even when one doesn't feel like it.</p>
<p><strong>Client:</strong> "I just can't eat anything. I have no appetite."</p>
<p><strong>Nurse:</strong> "I know you don't feel well, but it is important to begin eating." (validation; encouraging collaboration)</p>
<p><strong>Client:</strong> "I promise I'll eat just as soon as I'm hungry."</p>
