<p>Drugs in Schedule I have a high potential for abuse and have no approved medical use in the United States. Drugs in Schedules II through V all have approved uses and are classified based on their abuse potential. Schedule II drugs have a higher potential for abuse. Schedule V drugs have the lowest potential for abuse. Some individual states have or are considering laws, allowing medical and/or recreational use of marijuana. It remains Schedule I in this Federal law. Compiled from Controlled Substances Act. <a href="http://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/schedules/index" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/schedules/index</a>.</p>
<p>Glossary of Key Terms</p>
<p>12-step program based on the philosophy that total abstinence is essential and that alcoholics need the help and support of others to maintain sobriety</p>
<p>Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) tool used to screen for symptoms of movement disorders (side effects of neuroleptic medications)</p>
<p>abstract messages unclear patterns of words that often contain figures of speech that are difficult to interpret</p>
<p>abstract thinking ability to make associations or interpretations about a situation or comment abuse the wrongful use and maltreatment of another person</p>
<p>acceptance avoiding judgments of the person, no matter what the behavior</p>
<p>acculturation altering cultural values or behaviors as a way to adapt to another culture</p>
<p>acting out an immature defense mechanism by which the person deals with emotional conflicts or stressors through actions rather than through reflection or feelings</p>
<p>active listening concentrating exclusively on what the client says, refraining from other internal mental activities</p>
<p>active observation watching the speaker's nonverbal actions as he or she communicates</p>
<p>acute stress disorder diagnosis is appropriate when symptoms appear within the first month after the trauma and do not persist longer than 4 weeks</p>
<p>adaptive disclosure combat-specific therapy for veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD); eight sessions designed to help identify unhelpful beliefs about the trauma and find ways to move forward</p>
<p>adjustment disorder a group of symptoms, such as stress, feeling sad, or hopeless, and physical symptoms that occur following a stressful life event; the reaction is stronger than would-be expected for the event that</p>
<p>1109</p>
<p>occurred</p>
<p>advocacy the process of acting on the client’s behalf when he or she cannot do so</p>
<p>affect the outward expression of the client’s emotional state</p>
<p>agnosia inability to recognize or name objects despite intact sensory abilities</p>
<p>agoraphobia fear of being outside; from the Greek fear of the marketplace</p>
<p>akathisia intense need to move about; characterized by restless movement, pacing, inability to remain still, and the client’s report of inner restlessness</p>
<p>alexithymia difficulty identifying and expressing feelings</p>
<p>alogia a lack of any real meaning or substance in what the client says</p>
<p>alternative medicine therapies used in place of traditional or conventional medical practices</p>
<p>Alzheimer disease a progressive brain disorder that has a gradual onset but causes an increasing decline in functioning, including loss of speech, loss of motor function, and profound personality and behavioral changes such as those involving paranoia, delusions, hallucinations, inattention to hygiene, and belligerence</p>
<p>anergia lack of energy</p>
<p>anger a normal human emotion involving a strong, uncomfortable, emotional response to a real or perceived provocation</p>
<p>anhedonia having no pleasure or joy in life; losing any sense of pleasure from activities formerly enjoyed</p>
<p>anorexia nervosa an eating disorder characterized by the client’s refusal or inability to maintain a minimally normal body weight, intense fear of gaining weight or becoming fat, significantly disturbed perception of the shape or size of the body, and steadfast inability or refusal to acknowledge the existence or seriousness of a problem</p>
<p>anticholinergic effects dry mouth, constipation, urinary hesitancy or retention, dry nasal passages, and blurred near vision; commonly seen as side effects of medication</p>
<p>anticipatory grieving when people facing an imminent loss begin to grapple with the very real possibility of the loss or death in the near future</p>
<p>antidepressant drugs primarily used in the treatment of major depressive illness, anxiety disorders, the depressed phase of bipolar disorder, and psychotic depression</p>
<p>antipsychotic drugs also known as neuroleptics; used to treat the symptoms</p>
<p>1110</p>
<p>of psychosis such as the delusions and hallucinations seen in schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, and the manic phase of bipolar disorder</p>
<p>antisocial personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others and with the central characteristics of deceit and manipulation</p>
<p>anxiety a vague feeling of dread or apprehension; it is a response to external or internal stimuli that can have behavioral, emotional, cognitive, and physical symptoms</p>
<p>anxiety disorders a group of conditions that share a key feature of excessive anxiety, with ensuing behavioral, emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses</p>
<p>anxiolytic drugs used to treat anxiety and anxiety disorders, insomnia, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), depression, PTSD, and alcohol withdrawal</p>
<p>aphasia deterioration of language function</p>
<p>apraxia impaired ability to execute motor functions despite intact motor abilities</p>
<p>assault involves any action that causes a person to fear being touched, without consent or authority, in a way that is offensive, insulting, or physically injurious</p>
<p>assertive communication ability to express positive and negative ideas and feelings in an open, honest, and direct way</p>
<p>assertive community treatment (ACT) community-based programs that provide many of the services that are necessary for successful community living; includes case management, problem-solving, social skills training, support, teaching on a 24/7 basis</p>
<p>assertiveness training techniques using statements to identify feelings and communicate needs and concerns to others; helps the person negotiate interpersonal situations, fosters self-assurance, and ultimately assists the person to take more control over life situations</p>
<p>asylum a safe refuge or haven offering protection; in the United States, the term "asylum" was used to describe institutions for the mentally ill</p>
<p>attachment behaviors affectional bonds with significant others</p>
<p>attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) characterized by inattentiveness, overactivity, and impulsiveness</p>
<p>attentive presence being with the client and focusing intently on</p>
<p>1111</p>
<p>communicating with and understanding him or her</p>
<p><strong>attitudes</strong> general feelings or a frame of reference around which a person organizes knowledge about the world</p>
<p><strong>autism spectrum disorder</strong> neurodevelopmental disorder first seen in childhood, conceptualized across a continuum with symptoms varying from mild to severe; may include communication deficits, problems building social relationships, overdependence on routines, and high level of sensitivity to the environment</p>
<p><strong>automatism</strong> repeated, seemingly purposeless behaviors often indicative of anxiety, such as drumming fingers, twisting locks of hair, or tapping the foot; unconscious mannerism</p>
<p><strong>autonomy</strong> the person’s right to self-determination and independence</p>
<p><strong>avoidance behavior</strong> behavior designed to avoid unpleasant consequences or potentially threatening situations</p>
<p><strong>avoidant personality disorder</strong> characterized by a pervasive pattern of social discomfort and reticence, low self-esteem, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation</p>
<p><strong>battery</strong> involves harmful or unwarranted contact with a client; actual harm or injury may or may not have occurred</p>
<p><strong>behavior modification</strong> a method of attempting to strengthen a desired behavior or response by reinforcement, either positive or negative</p>
<p><strong>behaviorism</strong> a school of psychology that focuses on observable behaviors and what one can do externally to bring about behavior changes; it does not attempt to explain how the mind works</p>
<p><strong>beliefs</strong> ideas that one holds to be true</p>
<p><strong>beneficence</strong> refers to one’s duty to benefit or to promote good for others</p>
<p><strong>bereavement</strong> refers to the process by which a person experiences grief</p>
<p><strong>binge eating</strong> consuming a large amount of food (far greater than most people eat at one time) in a discrete period of usually 2 hours or less</p>
<p><strong>black box warning</strong> medication package inserts must have a highlighted box, separate from the text, that contains a warning about the life-threatening or otherwise serious side effect(s) of the medication</p>
<p><strong>blackout</strong> an episode during which the person continues to function but has no conscious awareness of his or her behavior at the time or any later memory of the behavior; usually associated with alcohol consumption</p>
<p><strong>blunted affect</strong> showing little or a slow-to-respond facial expression; few</p>
<p>1112</p>
<p>observable facial expressions</p>
<p>body image disturbance occurs when there is an extreme discrepancy between one's body image and the perceptions of others and extreme dissatisfaction with one's body image</p>
<p>body image how a person perceives his or her body, that is, a mental self-image</p>
<p>body language a nonverbal form of communication: gestures, postures, movements, and body positions</p>
<p>borderline personality disorder pervasive and enduring pattern of unstable interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affect; marked impulsivity; frequent self-mutilation behavior</p>
<p>breach of duty the nurse (or physician) failed to conform to standards of care, thereby breaching or failing the existing duty; the nurse did not act as a reasonable, prudent nurse would have acted in similar circumstances</p>
<p>broad affect displaying a full range of emotional expressions</p>
<p>bulimia nervosa an eating disorder characterized by recurrent episodes (at least twice a week for 3 months) of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors to avoid weight gain such as purging (self-induced vomiting or use of laxatives, diuretics, enemas, or emetics), fasting, or excessively exercising</p>
<p>callous and unemotional traits personality characteristics such as lack of empathy, lack of remorse for bad behavior, shallow or superficial emotions, and no concern for problematic behaviors or issues</p>
<p>case management management of care on a case-by-case basis, representing an effort to provide necessary services while containing cost; in the community, case management services include accessing medical and psychiatric services and providing assistance with tasks of daily living such as financial management, transportation, and buying groceries</p>
<p>catatonia psychomotor disturbance, either motionless or excessive motor</p>
<p>catharsis activities that are supposed to provide a release for strong feelings such as anger or rage</p>
<p>causation action that constitutes a breach of duty and was the direct cause of the loss, damage, or injury; in other words, the loss, damage, or injury would not have occurred if the nurse had acted in a reasonable, prudent manner</p>
<p>character consists of concepts about the self and the external world</p>
<p>child abuse the intentional injury of a child</p>
<p>1113</p>
<p>circumstantial thinking term used when a client eventually answers a question but only after giving excessive, unnecessary detail</p>
<p>circumstantiality the use of extraneous words and long, tedious descriptions</p>
<p>cliché an expression that has become trite and generally conveys a stereotype</p>
<p>client-centered therapy focused on the role of the client, rather than the therapist, as key to the healing process</p>
<p>closed body positions nonverbal behavior such as crossed legs and arms folded over chest that indicate the listener may be failing to listen, may be defensive, or not accepting</p>
<p>closed group structured to keep the same members in the group for a specified number of sessions</p>
<p>clubhouse model community-based rehabilitation; an “intentional community” based on the belief that both men and women with serious and persistent psychiatric disability can and will achieve normal life goals when given the opportunity, time, support, and fellowship</p>
<p>codependence a maladaptive coping pattern on the part of family members or others that results from a prolonged relationship with the person who uses substances</p>
<p>cognitive restructuring therapy that focuses on changing the way one thinks about or interprets one’s self, relationships, and/or environment</p>
<p>cognitive therapy focuses on immediate thought processing: how a person perceives or interprets his or her experience and determines how he or she feels and behaves</p>
<p>cognitive–behavioral techniques techniques useful in changing patterns of thinking by helping clients to recognize negative thoughts and to replace them with different patterns of thinking; include positive self-talk, decatastrophizing, positive reframing, and thought stopping</p>
<p>command hallucinations disturbed auditory sensory perceptions demanding that the client take action, often to harm self or others, and are considered dangerous; often referred to as “voices”</p>
<p>communication the processes that people use to exchange information</p>
<p>compassion fatigue a type of secondary trauma or stress resulting from helping others work through traumatic stress; experienced by those in the helping professions</p>
<p>compensatory behaviors for clients with eating disorders, actions designed to counteract food intake, such as purging (vomiting), excessively exercising, and using/abusing laxatives and diuretics</p>
<p>1114</p>
<p>complementary medicine therapies used in conjunction with traditional or conventional medical practices</p>
<p>complicated grieving a response outside the norm and occurring when a person is void of emotion, grieves for prolonged periods, or has expressions of grief that seem disproportionate to the event</p>
<p>compulsions ritualistic or repetitive behaviors or mental acts that a person carries out continuously in an attempt to neutralize anxiety</p>
<p>computed tomography (CT) a diagnostic procedure in which a precise x-ray beam takes cross-sectional images (slices) layer by layer</p>
<p>concrete message words that are as clear as possible when speaking to the client so that the client can understand the message; concrete messages are important for accurate information exchange</p>
<p>concrete thinking when the client continually gives literal translations; abstraction is diminished or absent</p>
<p>conduct disorder characterized by persistent antisocial behavior in children and adolescents that significantly impairs their ability to function in social, academic, or occupational areas</p>
<p>confabulation clients may make up answers to fill in memory gaps; usually associated with organic brain problems</p>
<p>confidentiality respecting the client's right to keep private any information about his or her mental and physical health and related care</p>
<p>confrontation technique designed to highlight the incongruence between a person's verbalizations and actual behavior; used to manage manipulative or deceptive behavior</p>
<p>congruence occurs when words and actions match</p>
<p>congruent message when communication content and processes agree</p>
<p>content verbal communication; the literal words that a person speaks</p>
<p>context the environment in which an event occurs; includes the time and the physical, social, emotional, and cultural environments</p>
<p>contract includes outlining the care the nurse will give, the times the nurse will be with the client, and acceptance of these conditions by the client</p>
<p>controlled substance drug classified under the Controlled Substances Act; includes opioids, stimulants, benzodiazepines, anabolic steroids, cannabis derivatives, psychedelics, and sedatives</p>
<p>conversion disorder sometimes called conversion reaction; involves unexplained, usually sudden deficits in sensory or motor function related</p>
<p>1115</p>
<p>to an emotional conflict the client experiences but does not handle directly</p>
<p>countertransference occurs when the therapist displaces onto the client attitudes or feelings from his or her past; process that can occur when the nurse responds to the client based on personal, unconscious needs and conflicts</p>
<p>Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease a central nervous system disorder that typically develops in adults 40 to 60 years of age and involves altered vision, loss of coordination or abnormal movements, and dementia</p>
<p>criminalization of mental illness refers to the practice of arresting and prosecuting mentally ill offenders, even for misdemeanors, at a rate four times that of the general population in an effort to contain them in some type of institution where they might receive needed treatment</p>
<p>crisis a turning point in an individual’s life that produces an overwhelming emotional response; life circumstance or stressor an individual is confronting that cannot be managed through customary coping strategies</p>
<p>crisis intervention includes a variety of techniques, based on the assessment of the individual in crisis, to assist in resolution or management of the stressor or circumstance</p>
<p>cues (overt and covert) verbal or nonverbal messages that signal keywords or issues for the client</p>
<p>culturally competent being sensitive to issues related to culture, race, gender, sexual orientation, social class, economic situation, and other factors</p>
<p>culture all the socially learned behaviors, values, beliefs, and customs, transmitted down to each generation, as well as a population’s ways of thinking that guide its members’ views of themselves and the world</p>
<p>cyberchondria excessive or repeated online searches for health-related information that is distressing or anxiety-provoking for the person</p>
<p>cycle of violence a typical pattern in domestic battering: violence; honeymoon or remorseful period; tension building; and, finally, violence; this pattern continually repeats itself throughout the relationship</p>
<p>date rape (acquaintance rape) sexual assault that may occur on a first date, on a ride home from a party or when the two people have known each other for some time</p>
<p>day treatment treatment programs in which clients attend during the day and return home or to the community at night</p>
<p>decarceration decriminalizing mental illness, allowing a shift from providing care of the mentally ill with minor legal offenses from jail and prison</p>
<p>1116</p>
<p>setting to treatment-focused programs</p>
<p><strong>decatastrophizing</strong> a technique that involves learning to assess situations realistically rather than always assuming a catastrophe will happen</p>
<p><strong>defense mechanisms</strong> cognitive distortions that a person uses unconsciously to maintain a sense of being in control of a situation, to lessen discomfort, and to deal with stress; also called ego defense mechanisms</p>
<p><strong>deinstitutionalization</strong> a deliberate shift in care of the mentally ill from institutional care in state hospitals to care in community-based facilities and through community-based services</p>
<p><strong>delirium</strong> a syndrome that involves a disturbance of consciousness accompanied by a change in cognition</p>
<p><strong>delusion</strong> a fixed, false belief not based in reality</p>
<p><strong>dementia</strong> a mental disorder that involves multiple cognitive deficits, initially involving memory impairment with progressive deterioration that includes all cognitive functioning</p>
<p><strong>denial</strong> defense mechanism; clients may deny directly having any problems or may minimize the extent of problems or actual substance use</p>
<p><strong>deontology</strong> a theory that states ethical decisions should be based on whether or not an action is morally right with no regard for the result or consequences</p>
<p><strong>dependent personality disorder</strong> characterized by a pervasive and excessive need to be taken care of, which leads to submissive and clinging behavior and fears of separation</p>
<p><strong>depersonalization</strong> feelings of being disconnected from himself or herself; the client feels detached from his or her behavior</p>
<p><strong>depot injection</strong> a slow-release, injectable form of antipsychotic medication for maintenance therapy</p>
<p><strong>depressive behavior</strong> characterized by a pervasive pattern of depressive cognitions and behaviors in various contexts</p>
<p><strong>derealization</strong> client senses that events are not real, when, in fact, they are</p>
<p><strong>dermatillomania</strong> compulsive skin picking, often to the point of physical damage; an impulse control disorder</p>
<p><strong>designer drugs</strong> synthetic substances made by altering existing medications or formulating new ones not yet controlled by the FDA; amphetamine-like effects, some also have hallucinogenic effects; called club drugs</p>
<p><strong>detoxification</strong> the process of safely withdrawing from a substance</p>
<p>1117</p>
<p>Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5) taxonomy published by the APA; the DSM-5 describes all mental disorders and outlines specific diagnostic criteria for each based on clinical experience and research</p>
<p>directive role asking direct, yes/no questions and using problem-solving to help the client develop new coping mechanisms to deal with present, here-and-now issues</p>
<p>disease conviction preoccupation with the fear that one has a serious disease</p>
<p>disease phobia preoccupation with the fear that one will get a serious disease</p>
<p>disenfranchised grief grief over a loss that is not or cannot be mourned publicly or supported socially</p>
<p>dissociation a subconscious defense mechanism that helps a person protect his or her emotional self from recognizing the full effects of some horrific or traumatic event by allowing the mind to forget or remove itself from the painful situation or memory</p>
<p>dissociative disorders these disorders have the essential feature of a disruption in the usually integrated functions of consciousness, memory, identity, or environmental perception; they include amnesia, fugue, and dissociative identity disorder</p>
<p>distance zones amount of physical space between people during communication; in the United States, Canada, and many Eastern European nations, four distance zones are generally observed: intimate zone, personal zone, social zone, and public zone</p>
<p>distraction involves shifting the client's attention and energy to a different topic</p>
<p>dopamine a neurotransmitter located primarily in the brain stem; has been found to be involved in the control of complex movements, motivation, cognition, and regulation of emotional responses</p>
<p>dream analysis a primary method used in psychoanalysis; involves discussing a client's dreams to discover their true meaning and significance</p>
<p>dual diagnosis the client with both substance abuse and another psychiatric illness</p>
<p>duty existence of a legally recognized relationship, that is, physician to client, nurse to client</p>
<p>duty to warn the exception to the client's right to confidentiality; when health care providers are legally obligated to warn another person who is the</p>
<p>1118</p>
<p>target of the threats or plan by the client, even if the threats were discussed during therapy sessions otherwise protected by confidentiality</p>
<p><strong>dysphoric</strong> mood that involves unhappiness, restlessness, and malaise</p>
<p><strong>dystonia</strong> extrapyramidal side effect to antipsychotic medication; includes acute muscular rigidity and cramping, a stiff or thick tongue with difficulty swallowing, and, in severe cases, laryngospasm and respiratory difficulties; also called dystonic reactions</p>
<p><strong>echolalia</strong> repetition or imitation of what someone else says; echoing what is heard</p>
<p><strong>echopraxia</strong> imitation of the movements and gestures of someone an individual is observing</p>
<p><strong>education group</strong> a therapeutic group; provides information to members on a specific issue, for instance, stress management, medication management, or assertiveness training</p>
<p><strong>efficacy</strong> refers to the maximal therapeutic effect a drug can achieve</p>
<p><strong>ego</strong> in psychoanalytic theory, the balancing or mediating force between the id and the superego; represents mature and adaptive behavior that allows a person to function successfully in the world</p>
<p><strong>elder abuse</strong> the maltreatment of older adults by family members or caretakers</p>
<p><strong>electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)</strong> used to treat depression in select groups such as clients who do not respond to antidepressants or those who experience intolerable medication side effects at therapeutic doses</p>
<p><strong>emotion-focused coping strategies</strong> techniques to assist clients to relax and reduce feelings of stress</p>
<p><strong>empathy</strong> the ability to perceive the meanings and feelings of another person and to communicate that understanding to that person</p>
<p><strong>enabling</strong> behaviors that seem helpful on the surface but actually perpetuate the substance use of another; for example, a wife who calls to report her husband has the flu and will miss work when he is actually drunk or hungover</p>
<p><strong>encopresis</strong> the repeated passage of feces into inappropriate places, such as clothing or the floor, by a child who is at least 4 years of age either chronologically or developmentally</p>
<p><strong>enmeshment</strong> lack of clear role boundaries between persons</p>
<p><strong>enuresis</strong> the repeated voiding of urine during the day or at night into clothing or bed by a child at least 5 years of age either chronologically or developmentally</p>
<p>1119</p>
<p>environmental control refers to a client's ability to control the surroundings or direct factors in the environment</p>
<p>epinephrine derivative of norepinephrine, the most prevalent neurotransmitter in the nervous system, located primarily in the brain stem, and plays a role in changes in attention, learning and memory, sleep and wakefulness, and mood regulation</p>
<p>ethical dilemma a situation in which ethical principles conflict or when there is no one clear course of action in a given situation</p>
<p>ethics a branch of philosophy that deals with values of human conduct related to the rightness or wrongness of actions and to the goodness and badness of the motives and ends of such actions</p>
<p>ethnicity concept of people identifying with one another based on a shared heritage</p>
<p>euthymic normal or level mood</p>
<p>evolving consumer household (ECH) a group-living situation in which the residents make the transition from a traditional group home to a residence where they fulfill their own responsibilities and function without onsite supervision from paid staff</p>
<p>executive functioning the ability to think abstractly and to plan, initiate, sequence, monitor, and stop complex behavior</p>
<p>exploitation phase of nurse-client relationship, identified by Peplau, when the nurse guides the client to examine feelings and responses and to develop better coping skills and a more positive self-image; this encourages behavior change and develops independence; part of the working phase</p>
<p>exposure behavioral technique that involves having the client deliberately confront the situations and stimuli that he or she is trying to avoid</p>
<p>externalizing behavior aggressive, angry, sometimes destructive behavior resulting from externalizing and acting out one's environmental stress and adversity</p>
<p>extrapyramidal side effects reversible movement disorders induced by antipsychotic or neuroleptic medication</p>
<p>extrapyramidal symptoms (EPSs) neurologic side effects of antipsychotic medications that are drug and dose related; treated with anticholinergic medication; includes dystonia, pseudoparkinsonism, and akathisia</p>
<p>eye contact looking into the other person's eyes during communication</p>
<p>fabricated and induced illness factitious disorders characterized by physical</p>
<p>1120</p>
<p>symptoms that are feigned or inflicted on one's self or another person for the sole purpose of gaining attention or other emotional benefits; also called factitious disorder, imposed on self or others</p>
<p><strong>false imprisonment</strong> the unjustifiable detention of a client, such as the inappropriate use of restraint or seclusion</p>
<p><strong>family therapy</strong> a form of group therapy in which the client and his or her family members participate to deal with mutual issues</p>
<p><strong>family violence</strong> encompasses domestic or partner battering; neglect and physical, emotional, or sexual abuse of children; elder abuse; and marital rape</p>
<p><strong>fear</strong> feeling afraid or threatened by a clearly identifiable, external stimulus that represents danger to the person</p>
<p><strong>fidelity</strong> refers to the obligation to honor commitments and contracts</p>
<p><strong>flat affect</strong> showing no facial expression</p>
<p><strong>flight of ideas</strong> excessive amount and rate of speech composed of fragmented or unrelated ideas; racing, often unconnected, thoughts</p>
<p><strong>flooding</strong> a form of rapid desensitization in which a behavioral therapist confronts the client with the phobic object (either a picture or the actual object) until it no longer produces anxiety</p>
<p><strong>flushing</strong> reddening of the face and neck as a result of increased blood flow</p>
<p><strong>free association</strong> a method in psychoanalysis used to gain access to subconscious thoughts and feelings in which the therapist tries to uncover the client's true thoughts and feelings by saying a word and asking the client to respond quickly with the first thing that comes to mind</p>
<p><strong>functional somatic syndrome</strong> see medically unexplained illness (MUS)</p>
<p><strong>genuine interest</strong> truly paying attention to the client, caring about what he or she is saying; only possible when the nurse is comfortable with himself or herself and aware of his or her strengths and limitations</p>
<p><strong>going along</strong> technique used with clients with dementia; providing emotional reassurance to clients without correcting their misperceptions or delusions</p>
<p><strong>grief</strong> subjective emotions and affect that are a normal response to the experience of loss</p>
<p><strong>grieving</strong> the process by which a person experiences grief</p>
<p><strong>grounding techniques</strong> helpful to use with the client who is dissociating or experiencing a flashback; grounding techniques remind the client that he or she is in the present, as an adult, and is safe</p>
<p>1121</p>
<p>group therapy therapy during which clients participate in sessions with others; the members share a common purpose and are expected to contribute to the group to benefit others and to receive benefit from others in return</p>
<p>half-life the time it takes for half of the drug to be eliminated from the bloodstream</p>
<p>hallucinations false sensory perceptions or perceptual experiences that do not really exist</p>
<p>hallucinogen substances that distort the user's perception of reality and produce symptoms similar to psychosis, including hallucinations (usually visual) and depersonalization</p>
<p>hardiness the ability to resist illness when under stress</p>
<p>hierarchy of needs a pyramid used to arrange and illustrate the basic drives or needs that motivate people; developed by Abraham Maslow</p>
<p>histrionic personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of excessive emotionality and attention seeking</p>
<p>homeostasis a state of equilibrium or balance</p>
<p>hostility an emotion expressed through verbal abuse, lack of cooperation, violation of rules or norms, or threatening behavior; also called verbal aggression</p>
<p>humanism focuses on a person's positive qualities, his or her capacity to change (human potential), and the promotion of self-esteem</p>
<p>Huntington disease an inherited, dominant gene disease that primarily involves cerebral atrophy, demyelination, and enlargement of the brain ventricles</p>
<p>hyperarousal symptoms that arise from high levels of anxiety, including insomnia, irritability, anger outbursts, watchfulness, suspiciousness, and distrustfulness. Often seen with PTSD</p>
<p>hypertensive crisis a life-threatening condition that can result when a client taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) ingests tyramine-containing foods and fluids or other medications</p>
<p>hypochondriasis see illness anxiety disorder</p>
<p>hypomania a period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting 4 days; does not impair the ability to function and does not involve psychotic features</p>
<p>hysteria refers to multiple, recurrent physical complaints with no organic basis</p>
<p>1122</p>
<p>id in psychoanalytic theory, the part of one’s nature that reflects basic or innate desires such as pleasure-seeking behavior, aggression, and sexual impulses; the id seeks instant gratification; causes impulsive, unthinking behavior; and has no regard for rules or social convention</p>
<p>ideas of reference client’s inaccurate interpretation that general events are personally directed to him or her, such as hearing a speech on the news and believing the message has personal meaning</p>
<p>illness anxiety disorder preoccupation with the fear that one has a serious disease or will get a serious disease; also called hypochondriasis</p>
<p>impulse control the ability to delay gratification and to think about one’s behavior before acting</p>
<p>inappropriate affect displaying a facial expression that is incongruent with mood or situation; often silly or giddy regardless of circumstances</p>
<p>incongruent message when the communication content and process disagree</p>
<p>individual psychotherapy a method of bringing about change in a person by exploring his or her feelings, attitudes, thinking, and behavior; it involves a one-to-one relationship between the therapist and the client</p>
<p>inhalant a diverse group of drugs including anesthetics, nitrates, and organic solvents that are inhaled for their effects</p>
<p>injury or damage the client suffered some type of loss, damage, or injury</p>
<p>insight the ability to understand the true nature of one’s situation and accept some personal responsibility for that situation</p>
<p>interdisciplinary (multidisciplinary) team treatment group composed of individuals from a variety of fields or disciplines; the most useful approach in dealing with the multifaceted problems of clients with mental illness</p>
<p>intergenerational transmission process explains that patterns of violence are perpetuated from one generation to the next through role modeling and social learning</p>
<p>internalization keeping stress, anxiety, or frustration inside rather than expressing them outwardly</p>
<p>internalizing behavior isolative and withdrawn behavior, as well as somatic illness, depression, and anxiety resulting from internalizing one’s environmental stress and adversity</p>
<p>intimate partner violence the mistreatment, misuse, or abuse of one person by another in the context of a close, personal, or committed relationship</p>
<p>intimate relationship a relationship involving two people who are</p>
<p>1123</p>
<p>emotionally committed to each other; both parties are concerned about having their individual needs met and helping each other to meet needs as well; the relationship may include sexual or emotional intimacy as well as sharing of mutual goals</p>
<p>intimate zone space of 0 to 18 in between people; the amount of space comfortable for parents with young children, people who mutually desire personal contact, or people whispering; invasion of this intimate zone by anyone else is threatening and produces anxiety</p>
<p>intoxication use of a substance that results in maladaptive behavior</p>
<p>judgment refers to the ability to interpret one's environment and situation correctly and to adapt one's behavior and decisions accordingly</p>
<p>justice refers to fairness, or treating all people fairly and equally without regard for social or economic status, race, sex, marital status, religion, ethnicity, or cultural beliefs</p>
<p>kindling process the snowball-like effect seen when a minor seizure activity seems to build up into more frequent and severe seizures</p>
<p>Korsakoff syndrome type of dementia caused by long-term, excessive alcohol intake that results in a chronic thiamine or vitamin B deficiency</p>
<p>la belle indifférence a seeming lack of concern or distress; a key feature of conversion disorder</p>
<p>labile rapidly changing or fluctuating, such as someone's mood or emotions</p>
<p>latency of response refers to hesitation before the client responds to questions</p>
<p>least restrictive environment treatment appropriate to meet the client's needs with only necessary or required restrictions</p>
<p>limbic system an area of the brain located above the brain stem that includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, hippocampus, and amygdala (although some sources differ regarding the structures that this system includes)</p>
<p>limit setting an effective technique that involves three steps: stating the behavioral limit (describing the unacceptable behavior), identifying the consequences if the limit is exceeded, and identifying the expected or desired behavior</p>
<p>loose associations disorganized thinking that jumps from one idea to another with little or no evident relation between the thoughts</p>
<p>magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) diagnostic test used to visualize soft-tissue structures; energy field is created with a magnet and radio waves and then converted into a visual image</p>
<p>malingering the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated</p>
<p>1124</p>
<p>physical or psychological symptoms</p>
<p>malpractice a type of negligence that refers specifically to professionals such as nurses and physicians</p>
<p>managed care a concept designed to purposely control the balance between the quality of care provided and the cost of that care</p>
<p>managed care organizations developed to control the expenditure of insurance funds by requiring providers to seek approval before the delivery of care</p>
<p>mania a distinct period during which mood is abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable</p>
<p>medically unexplained symptoms (MUS) Physical symptoms and limitations of function that have no medical diagnosis to explain their existence. See functional somatic syndrome</p>
<p>mental health a state of emotional, psychological, and social wellness evidenced by satisfying relationships, effective behavior and coping, positive self-concept, and emotional stability</p>
<p>mental illness a clinically significant behavioral or psychological syndrome or pattern that occurs in an individual and that is associated with present distress (e.g., a painful symptom) or disability (i.e., impairment in one or more important areas of functioning) or with a significantly increased risk of suffering death, pain, disability, or an important loss of freedom</p>
<p>metaphor a phrase that describes an object or a situation by comparing it to something else familiar</p>
<p>mild anxiety a sensation that something is different and warrants special attention</p>
<p>milieu therapy the concept involves clients' interactions with one another, that is, practicing interpersonal relationship skills, giving one another feedback about behavior, and working cooperatively as a group to solve day-to-day problems</p>
<p>moderate anxiety the disturbing feeling that something is definitely wrong; the person becomes nervous or agitated</p>
<p>mood disorders pervasive alterations in emotions that are manifested by depression or mania or both</p>
<p>mood refers to the client's pervasive and enduring emotional state</p>
<p>mood-stabilizing drugs used to treat bipolar disorder by stabilizing the client's mood, preventing or minimizing the highs and lows that characterize bipolar illness, and treating acute episodes of mania</p>
<p>1125</p>
<p>mourning the outward expression of grief
Munchausen syndrome a factitious disorder where the person intentionally causes injury or physical symptoms to self to gain attention and sympathy from health care providers, family, and others
Munchausen syndrome by proxy when a person inflicts illness or injury on someone else to gain the attention of emergency medical personnel or to be a hero for "saving" the victim
narcissistic personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of grandiosity (in fantasy or behavior), need for admiration, and lack of empathy
negative reinforcement involves removing a stimulus immediately after a behavior occurs so that the behavior is more likely to occur again
neglect malicious or ignorant withholding of physical, emotional, or educational necessities for the child's well-being
negligence an unintentional tort that involves causing harm by failing to do what a reasonable and prudent person would do in similar circumstances
neologisms invented words that have meaning only for the client
neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) a potentially fatal, idiosyncratic reaction to an antipsychotic (or neuroleptic) drug
neuroleptics antipsychotic medications
neurotransmitter the chemical substances manufactured in the neuron that aid in the transmission of information throughout the body
nondirective role using broad openings and open-ended questions to collect information and help the client to identify and discuss the topic of concern
nonmaleficence the requirement to do no harm to others either intentionally or unintentionally
nonsuicidal self-injury intentional physical damage to the body, such as cutting or burning; results from self-harm urges or thoughts; injury is not an attempt at suicide
nonverbal communication the behavior that accompanies verbal content, such as body language, eye contact, facial expression, tone of voice, speed and hesitations in speech, grunts and groans, and distance from the listener
norepinephrine the most prevalent neurotransmitter in the nervous system
no-self-harm contract a client promises to not engage in self-harm and to report to the nurse when he or she is losing control
obsessions recurrent, persistent, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts, images, or</p>
<p>1126</p>
<p>impulses that cause marked anxiety and interfere with interpersonal, social, or occupational function</p>
<p>obsessive-compulsive personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with perfectionism, mental and interpersonal control, and orderliness at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency</p>
<p>off-label use a drug will prove effective for a disease that differs from the one involved in original testing and FDA approval</p>
<p>oniomania compulsive buying; possessions are acquired compulsively without regard for cost or need for the item</p>
<p>onychophagia compulsive nail biting</p>
<p>open group an ongoing group that runs indefinitely; members join or leave the group as they need to</p>
<p>operant conditioning the theory that says people learn their behavior from their history or past experiences, particularly those experiences that were repeatedly reinforced</p>
<p>opioid controlled drugs; often abused because they desensitize the user to both physiological and psychological pain and induce a sense of euphoria and well-being; some are prescribed for analgesic effects, but others are illegal in the United States</p>
<p>orientation phase the beginning of the nurse-client relationship; begins when the nurse and client meet and ends when the client begins to identify problems to examine</p>
<p>orthorexia (nervosa) pathological obsession with healthy eating or a "pure" diet; dedication to extreme diets, often to the detriment of health</p>
<p>pain disorder has the primary physical symptom of pain, which generally is unrelieved by analgesics and greatly affected by psychological factors in terms of onset, severity, exacerbation, and maintenance</p>
<p>palilalia repeating words or sounds over and over</p>
<p>panic anxiety intense anxiety, may be a response to a life-threatening situation</p>
<p>panic attack between 15 and 30 minutes of rapid, intense, escalating anxiety in which the person experiences great emotional fear as well as physiological discomfort</p>
<p>panic disorder composed of discrete episodes of panic attacks, that is, 15 to 30 minutes of rapid, intense, escalating anxiety in which the person experiences great emotional fear as well as physiological discomfort</p>
<p>1127</p>
<p>paranoid personality disorder characterized by pervasive mistrust and suspiciousness of others</p>
<p>parataxic mode begins in early childhood as the child begins to connect experiences in sequence; the child may not make logical sense of the experiences and may see them as coincidence or chance events; the child seeks to relieve anxiety by repeating familiar experiences, although he or she may not understand what he or she is doing</p>
<p>Parkinson disease a slowly progressive neurologic condition characterized by tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability</p>
<p>partial hospitalization program (PHP) structured treatment at an agency or a facility for clients living in the community; designed to help clients make a gradual transition from being an inpatient to living independently or to avoid hospital admission</p>
<p>participant observer this term has been coined for the therapist's role, meaning that the therapist both participates in and observes the progress of the relationship</p>
<p>passive-aggressive behavior characterized by a negative attitude and a pervasive pattern of passive resistance to demands for adequate social and occupational performance</p>
<p>patterns of knowing the four patterns of knowing in nursing are empirical knowing (derived from the science of nursing), personal knowing (derived from life experiences), ethical knowing (derived from moral knowledge of nursing), and aesthetic knowing (derived from the art of nursing); these patterns provide the nurse with a clear method of observing and understanding every client interaction</p>
<p>personal zone space of 18 to 36 in; a comfortable distance between family and friends who are talking</p>
<p>personality an ingrained, enduring pattern of behaving and relating to self, others, and the environment; includes perceptions, attitudes, and emotions</p>
<p>personality disorders diagnosed when personality traits become inflexible and maladaptive and significantly interfere with how a person functions in society or cause the person emotional distress</p>
<p>phenomena of concern describe the 12 areas of concern that mental health nurses focus on when caring for clients</p>
<p>phobia an illogical, intense, and persistent fear of a specific object or social situation that causes extreme distress and interferes with normal functioning</p>
<p>1128</p>
<p>physical abuse ranges from shoving and pushing to severe battering and choking and may involve broken limbs and ribs, internal bleeding, brain damage, and even homicide</p>
<p>physical aggression behavior in which a person attacks or injures another person or that involves destruction of property</p>
<p>pica persistent ingestion of nonnutritive substances such as paint, hair, cloth, leaves, sand, clay, or soil</p>
<p>Pick disease a degenerative brain disease that particularly affects the frontal and temporal lobes and results in a clinical picture similar to that of Alzheimer disease</p>
<p>polydipsia excessive water intake</p>
<p>polysubstance abuse abuse of more than one substance</p>
<p>positive reframing a cognitive-behavioral technique involving turning negative messages into positive ones</p>
<p>positive regard unconditional, nonjudgmental attitude that implies respect for the person</p>
<p>positive reinforcement a reward immediately following a behavior to increase the likelihood that the behavior will be repeated</p>
<p>positive self-talk a cognitive-behavioral technique in which the client changes thinking about the self from negative to positive</p>
<p>positron emission tomography (PET) a diagnostic test used to examine the function of the brain by monitoring the flow of radioactive substances that are injected into the bloodstream</p>
<p>postinjection delirium/sedation syndrome (PDSS) cluster of symptoms, such as slurred speech, confusion, sedation, altered gait, or unconsciousness that result from accidental intravascular injection of a portion of olanzapine (Zyprexa Relprevv)</p>
<p>posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) a disturbing pattern of behavior demonstrated by someone who has experienced a traumatic event; for example, a natural disaster, a combat, or an assault; begins 3 months or more following the trauma</p>
<p>potency describes the amount of a drug needed to achieve maximum effect</p>
<p>preconception the way one person expects another to behave or speak; often a roadblock to the formation of an authentic relationship</p>
<p>pressured speech unrelenting, rapid, often loud talking without pauses</p>
<p>primary gain the relief of anxiety achieved by performing the specific</p>
<p>1129</p>
<p>anxiety-driven behavior; the direct internal benefits that being sick provides, such as relief of anxiety, conflict, or distress</p>
<p><strong>problem identification</strong> part of the working phase of the nurse-client situation, when the client identifies the issues or concerns causing problems</p>
<p><strong>problem-focused coping strategies</strong> techniques used to resolve or change a person’s behavior or situation or to manage life stressors</p>
<p><strong>process</strong> in communication, denotes all nonverbal messages that the speaker uses to give meaning and context to the message</p>
<p><strong>prototaxic mod</strong> characteristic of infancy and childhood that involves brief, unconnected experiences that have no relationship to one another; adults with schizophrenia exhibit persistent prototaxic experiences</p>
<p><strong>proverbs</strong> old adages or sayings with generally accepted meanings</p>
<p><strong>proxemics</strong> the study of distance zones between people during communication</p>
<p><strong>pseudoparkinsonism</strong> a type of extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medication; drug-induced parkinsonism; includes shuffling gait, masklike facies, muscle stiffness (continuous) or cogwheeling rigidity (ratchet-like movements of joints), drooling, and akinesia (slowness and difficulty initiating movement)</p>
<p><strong>psychiatric rehabilitation</strong> services designed to promote the recovery process for clients with mental illness; not limited to medication management and symptom control; includes personal growth reintegration into the community, increased independence, and improved quality of life</p>
<p><strong>psychoanalysis</strong> focuses on discovering the causes of the client’s unconscious and repressed thoughts, feelings, and conflicts believed to cause anxiety and helping the client to gain insight into and resolve these conflicts and anxieties; pioneered by Sigmund Freud; not commonly seen today</p>
<p><strong>psychoimmunology</strong> examines the effect of psychosocial stressors on the body’s immune system</p>
<p><strong>psychological abuse (emotional abuse)</strong> includes name calling, belittling, screaming, yelling, destroying property, and making threats as well as subtler forms such as refusing to speak to or ignoring the victim</p>
<p><strong>psychomotor agitation</strong> increased body movements and thoughts</p>
<p><strong>psychomotor retardation</strong> overall slowed movements; a general slowing of all movements; slow cognitive processing and slow verbal interaction</p>
<p><strong>psychopharmacology</strong> the use of medications to treat mental illness</p>
<p><strong>psychosis</strong> cluster of symptoms including delusions, hallucinations, and</p>
<p>1130</p>
<p>grossly disordered thinking and behavior</p>
<p>psychosocial interventions nursing activities that enhance the client's social and psychological functioning and improve social skills, interpersonal relationships, and communication</p>
<p>psychosomatic used to convey the connection between the mind (psyche) and the body (soma) in states of health and illness</p>
<p>psychotherapy group the goal of the group is for members to learn about their behaviors and to make positive changes in their behaviors by interacting and communicating with others as members of a group</p>
<p>psychotherapy therapeutic interaction between a qualified provider and a client or group designed to benefit persons experiencing emotional distress, impairment, or illness; therapist's approach is based on a theory or combination of theories</p>
<p>psychotropic drugs drugs that affect mood, behavior, and thinking that are used to treat mental illness</p>
<p>public zone space of 12 to 25 ft; the acceptable distance between a speaker and an audience, between small groups, and among others at informal functions</p>
<p>purging compensatory behaviors designed to eliminate food by means of self-induced vomiting</p>
<p>race a division of humankind possessing traits that are transmitted by descent and sufficient to identify it as a distinct human type</p>
<p>rape a crime of violence, domination, and humiliation of the victim expressed through sexual means</p>
<p>rebound temporary return of symptoms; may be more intense than original symptoms</p>
<p>recovery improved quality of life, beyond just symptom control, including personal growth, reintegration into the community, empowerment, increased independence, and pursuit of life goals like any other person</p>
<p>reframing cognitive-behavioral technique in which alternative points of view are examined to explain events</p>
<p>religion an organized system of beliefs about one or more all-powerful, all-knowing forces that govern the universe and offer guidelines for living in harmony with the universe and others</p>
<p>reminiscence therapy thinking about or relating personally significant past experiences in a purposeful manner to benefit the client</p>
<p>repressed memories memories that are buried deeply in the subconscious</p>
<p>1131</p>
<p>mind or repressed because they are too painful for the victim to acknowledge; often relate to childhood abuse</p>
<p><strong>residential treatment setting</strong> long-term treatment provided in a living situation; vary according to structure, level of supervision, and services provided</p>
<p><strong>resilience</strong> defined as having healthy responses to stressful circumstances or risky situations</p>
<p><strong>resourcefulness</strong> involves using problem-solving abilities and believing that one can cope with adverse or novel situations</p>
<p><strong>response prevention</strong> behavioral technique that focuses on delaying or avoiding performance of rituals in response to anxiety-provoking thoughts</p>
<p><strong>restraining order</strong> legal order of protection obtained to prohibit contact between a victim and a perpetrator of abuse</p>
<p><strong>restraint</strong> the direct application of physical force to a person, without his or her permission, to restrict his or her freedom of movement</p>
<p><strong>restricted affect</strong> displaying one type of emotional expression, usually serious or somber</p>
<p><strong>rumination</strong> repeatedly going over the same thoughts</p>
<p><strong>satiety</strong> satisfaction of appetite</p>
<p><strong>schizoid personality disorder</strong> characterized by a pervasive pattern of detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression in interpersonal settings</p>
<p><strong>schizotypal personality disorder</strong> characterized by a pervasive pattern of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with and reduced capacity for close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and behavioral eccentricities</p>
<p><strong>seasonal affective disorder (SAD)</strong> mood disorder with two subtypes; in one, most commonly called winter depression or fall-onset SAD, people experience increased sleep, appetite, and carbohydrate cravings; weight gain; interpersonal conflict; irritability; and heaviness in the extremities beginning in late autumn and abating in spring and summer; the other subtype, called spring-onset SAD, is less common and includes symptoms of insomnia, weight loss, and poor appetite lasting from late spring or early summer until early fall</p>
<p><strong>seclusion</strong> the involuntary confinement of a person in a specially constructed, locked room equipped with a security window or camera for direct visual monitoring</p>
<p>1132</p>
<p>secondary gain the external benefits received from others because one is sick, such as attention from family members, comfort measures, and being excused from usual responsibilities or tasks</p>
<p>self-actualized describes a person who has achieved all the needs according to Maslow's hierarchy and has developed his or her fullest potential in life</p>
<p>self-awareness the process by which a person gains recognition of his or her own feelings, beliefs, and attitudes; the process of developing an understanding of one's own values, beliefs, thoughts, feelings, attitudes, motivations, prejudices, strengths, and limitations and how these qualities affect others</p>
<p>self-concept the way one views oneself in terms of personal worth and dignity</p>
<p>self-disclosure revealing personal information such as biographical information and personal experiences, ideas, thoughts, and feelings about oneself</p>
<p>self-efficacy a belief that personal abilities and efforts affect the events in our lives</p>
<p>self-help group members share a common experience, but the group is not a formal or structured therapy group</p>
<p>self-monitoring a cognitive-behavioral technique designed to help clients manage their own behavior</p>
<p>sense of belonging the feeling of connectedness with involvement in a social system or environment of which a person feels an integral part</p>
<p>serotonin a neurotransmitter found only in the brain</p>
<p>serotonin syndrome uncommon but potentially life-threatening disorder called serotonin or serotonergic syndrome; characterized by agitation, sweating, fever, tachycardia, hypotension, rigidity, hyperreflexia, confusion, and, in extreme cases, coma and death; most commonly results from a combination of two or more medications with serotonin-enhancing properties, such as taking MAOI and SSRI antidepressants at the same time or too close together</p>
<p>severe anxiety an increased level of anxiety when more primitive survival skills take over, defensive responses ensue, and cognitive skills decrease significantly; person with severe anxiety has trouble thinking and reasoning</p>
<p>sexual abuse involves sexual acts performed by an adult on a child younger than 18 years</p>
<p>single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) a diagnostic test</p>
<p>1133</p>
<p>used to examine the function of the brain by following the flow of an injected radioactive substance</p>
<p>sluggish cognitive tempo (SCT) syndrome including day dreaming, trouble focusing and paying attention, mental fogginess, staring, sleepiness, little interest in physical activity, and slow to finish tasks</p>
<p>social network groups of people whom one knows and with whom one feels connected</p>
<p>social organization refers to family structure and organization, religious values and beliefs, ethnicity, and culture, all of which affect a person's role and, therefore, his or her health and illness behavior</p>
<p>social relationship primarily initiated for the purpose of friendship, socialization, companionship, or accomplishment of a task</p>
<p>social support emotional sustenance that comes from friends, family members, and even health care providers who help a person when a problem arises</p>
<p>social zone a space of 4 to 12 ft, which is the distance acceptable for communication in social, work, and business settings</p>
<p>socioeconomic status refers to one's income, education, and occupation</p>
<p>sodomy anal intercourse</p>
<p>somatic symptom disorder characterized by multiple, recurrent physical symptoms in a variety of bodily systems that have no organic or medical basis; also called somatization disorder</p>
<p>somatization the transference of mental experiences and states into bodily symptoms</p>
<p>spirituality a client's beliefs about life, health, illness, death, and one's relationship to the universe; involves the essence of a person's being and his or her beliefs about the meaning of life and the purpose for living</p>
<p>spontaneous remission natural recovery that occurs without treatment of any kind</p>
<p>spouse or partner abuse see intimate partner violence</p>
<p>stalking repeated and persistent attempts to impose unwanted communication or contact on another person</p>
<p>standards of care authoritative statements by professional organizations that describe the responsibilities for which nurses are accoTABLE; the care that nurses provide to clients meets set expectations and is what any nurse in a similar situation would do</p>
<p>1134</p>
<p>stereotyped motor behavior repetitive, seemingly purposeless movements; may include waving, rocking, twirling objects, biting fingernails, banging the head, biting or hitting oneself, or picking at the skin or body orifices</p>
<p>stimulant drugs drugs that stimulate or excite the central nervous system</p>
<p>stress the wear and tear that life causes on the body</p>
<p>subconscious thoughts or feelings in the preconscious or unconscious level of awareness</p>
<p>substance abuse can be defined as using a drug in a way that is inconsistent with medical or social norms and despite negative consequences</p>
<p>substance dependence includes problems associated with addiction, such as tolerance, withdrawal, and unsuccessful attempts to stop using the substance</p>
<p>suicidal ideation thinking about killing oneself</p>
<p>suicide precautions removal of harmful items; increased supervision to prevent acts of self-harm</p>
<p>suicide the intentional act of killing oneself</p>
<p>superego in psychoanalytic theory, the part of a person's nature that reflects moral and ethical concepts, values, and parental and social expectations; therefore, it is in direct opposition to the id</p>
<p>support group organized to help members who share a common problem to cope with it</p>
<p>supportive touch the use of physical touch to convey support, interest, caring; may not be welcome or effective with all clients</p>
<p>survivor view of the client as a survivor of trauma or abuse rather than as a victim; helps to refocus client's view of himself or herself as being strong enough to survive the ordeal, which is a more empowering image than seeing oneself as a victim</p>
<p>syntaxic mode begins to appear in school-aged children and becomes more predominant in preadolescence; the person begins to perceive himself or herself and the world within the context of the environment and can analyze experiences in a variety of settings</p>
<p>systematic desensitization behavioral technique used to help overcome irrational fears and anxiety associated with a phobia</p>
<p>tangential thinking wandering off the topic and never providing the information requested</p>
<p>tapering administering decreasing doses of a medication, leading to</p>
<p>1135</p>
<p>discontinuation of the drug</p>
<p>tardive dyskinesia a late-onset, irreversible neurologic side effect of antipsychotic medications; characterized by abnormal, involuntary movements such as lip smacking, tongue protrusion, chewing, blinking, grimacing, and choreiform movements of the limbs and feet</p>
<p>temperament refers to the biologic processes of sensation, association, and motivation that underlie the integration of skills and habits based on emotion</p>
<p>termination or resolution phase the final stage in the nurse-client relationship; it begins when the client's problems are resolved and concludes when the relationship ends</p>
<p>therapeutic communication an interpersonal interaction between the nurse and the client during which the nurse focuses on the client's specific needs to promote an effective exchange of information</p>
<p>therapeutic community or milieu beneficial environment; interaction among clients is seen as beneficial, and treatment emphasizes the role of this client-to-client interaction</p>
<p>therapeutic nurse-client relationship professional, planned relationship between the client and the nurse that focuses on client needs, feelings, problems, and ideas; interaction designed to promote client growth, discuss issues, and resolve problems; includes the three phases of orientation: working (identification and exploitation) and termination (resolution); also called therapeutic nurse-patient relationship</p>
<p>therapeutic play play techniques are used to understand the child's thoughts and feelings and to promote communication</p>
<p>therapeutic relationship see therapeutic nurse-client relationship</p>
<p>therapeutic use of self nurses use themselves as a therapeutic tool to establish the therapeutic relationship with clients and to help clients grow, change, and heal</p>
<p>thought blocking stopping abruptly in the middle of a sentence or train of thought; sometimes, the client is unable to continue the idea</p>
<p>thought broadcasting a delusional belief that others can hear or know what the client is thinking</p>
<p>thought content what the client actually says</p>
<p>thought insertion a delusional belief that others are putting ideas or thoughts into the client's head; that is, the ideas are not those of the client</p>
<p>thought process how the client thinks</p>
<p>1136</p>
<p>thought stopping a cognitive-behavioral technique to alter the process of negative or self-critical thought patterns</p>
<p>thought withdrawal a delusional belief that others are taking the client's thoughts away and the client is powerless to stop it</p>
<p>tic a sudden, rapid, recurrent, nonrhythmic, stereotyped motor movement or vocalization</p>
<p>time away involves leaving clients for a short period and then returning to them to reengage in interaction; used in dementia care</p>
<p>time orientation whether or not one views time as precise or approximate; differs among cultures</p>
<p>time-out retreat to a neutral place to give the opportunity to regain self-control</p>
<p>tolerance break very small amounts of a substance will produce intoxication</p>
<p>tolerance the need for increased amount of a substance to produce the same effect</p>
<p>tort a wrongful act that results in injury, loss, or damage</p>
<p>Tourette disorder involves multiple motor tics and one or more vocal tics, which occur many times a day for more than 1 year</p>
<p>transference occurs when the client displaces onto the therapist attitudes and feelings that the client originally experienced in other relationships; it is common for the client to unconsciously transfer to the nurse feelings he or she has for significant others</p>
<p>trichotillomania compulsive hair pulling from scalp, eyebrows, or other parts of the body; leaves patchy bald spots that the person tries to conceal</p>
<p>unknowing when the nurse admits she does not know the client or the client's subjective world; this opens the way for a truly authentic encounter; the nurse in a state of unknowing is open to seeing and hearing the client's views without imposing any of his or her values or viewpoints</p>
<p>utilitarianism a theory that bases ethical decisions on the "greatest good for the greatest number"; primary consideration is on the outcome of the decision</p>
<p>utilization review firms developed to control the expenditure of insurance funds by requiring providers to seek approval before the delivery of care</p>
<p>values abstract standards that give a person a sense of right and wrong and establish a code of conduct for living</p>
<p>vascular dementia has symptoms similar to those of Alzheimer disease, but</p>
<p>1137</p>
<p>the onset is typically abrupt and followed by rapid changes in functioning, a plateau or leveling-off period, more abrupt changes, another leveling-off period, and so on</p>
<p><strong>veracity</strong> the duty to be honest or truthful</p>
<p><strong>verbal communication</strong> the words a person uses to speak to one or more listeners</p>
<p><strong>waxy flexibility</strong> maintenance of posture or position over time even when it is awkward or uncomfortable</p>
<p><strong>withdrawal</strong> new symptoms resulting from discontinuation of drug or substance</p>
<p><strong>withdrawal syndrome</strong> refers to the negative psychological and physical reactions that occur when use of a substance ceases or dramatically decreases</p>
<p><strong>word salad flow</strong> of unconnected words that convey no meaning to the listener</p>
<p><strong>working phase</strong> in the therapeutic relationship, the phase where issues are addressed, problems identified, and solutions explored; both nurse and client work to accomplish goals; contains Peplau’s phases of problem identification and exploitation</p>
<p>1138</p>
<p>Index</p>

<p>Anxiety
